, hiding something under a sand heap; after they were gone we went and raked the sand up, and found a sack with lead in it - we took and put it into a sand house, not far from the heap - we staid a short time longer, and then took up the nets - this was in the afternoon, but before dinner we went home, and returned in about half an hour to go bird's nesting, and saw the two prisoners sitting in the field with Rowley and White - they were swearing; I asked what was the matter, and Harris said some one had sprung the plant - I asked what he meant- he said some one had taken some lead of theirs - I asked what he would give if he knew who had it - he said"Two pots of beer and a punch of the head;" I did not stay any longer - next day I and a young man, named Hunt, were out bird's nesting - I told him what happened, and he said "We may as well go and get it" - we did so, and, as we were going down the town, we met Carver, the beadle, who stopped us - he took the lead - I went before the Magistrate and gave evidence.

NATHAN ADAMS
. I was in the field with Gardner - I have heard what he has said, and it is true - I saw Harris and Rowley come to the spot; I saw Gardner and Hunt take the lead, but I was not with them when they were stopped - Ayres was not there the first time, but he was the second.

ALEXANDER ALLEN
. I was with Gardner. I saw Rowley and Harris come into the field, and Earl stood at the gate - they put something into the sand - we went and took it out - it was then between twelve and one o'clock- I did not see the man come the second time.

THOMAS EARL
. I was taken up about this matter, and examined by the Justice - he told me to say nothing, as it might hurt myself. I was at the Angel public-house, at Isleworth, on Friday evening, about nine o'clock- Harris, Ayres, and White were there; we all said, "Let us get a few turnips;" we walked by the Chaise and Horses public-house, and Harris said, "Let us go and get something worth while;" he took us up to Sion-lane - I did not know what he was going after till we came past Mr. Iron's; Ayres, Harris, and White then got over the pales - I could hardly get over, but Ayres eased me over, and we went on till we came to the cow yard - there are some pales round it, and some persons live in the little house by the side of the barn. Ayres and Harris got over the pales - White lifted me over; I waited there - Harris and Ayres got on the top of the cow shed; I heard them pulling the tiles off, and I ran to the other side of the pales. Harris called to White to ease it off the tiles - I did not then know what it was; I went up, and saw White under the tiles, with the lead on his shoulder. - Ayres and Harris got off the tiles, and carried it through the field, till they came to the hedge - Harris then lifted it on White's back, and they got on the sand heap in the Whale field, where they divided it into three pieces - this is one of them; Ayres sold one piece for 2s. 2d., and I sold one for 2s. 3d., and gave the money to Ayres, who shared it; the third piece was left in the sand house, under the straw; we went away; the next day Ayres, Harris, Rowley, and I, went birds' nesting; Harris and Rowley were a-head of us, and got into the Whale field, about a quarter of an hour before we did. I did not see the witness in the field; I heard Harris say somebody had sprang the plant, and I saw Gardner go and say, "What would you give to know who it was?" he said, "I would not mind two pots of beer and a punch of the head."

JOHN COE
. I am a carpenter. I have compared this lead with that on the building of His Grace the Duke of Northumberland, and I have no doubt it had been taken from there - this is about a quarter of it.

JOHN CARVER
. I am a beadle. I took the lead, and saw it fitted on the premises - it seemed to fit exactly.

COURT to
THOMAS NEALE
. Q. How lately had you seen the building before the lead was taken? A. Perhaps a fortnight or three weeks. I saw the lead fitted upon the building - the part that remains is fixed down.

HARRIS -
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Seven Years .

AYRES -
NOT GUILTY .

811.
CHARLES POWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of April , at Hillingdon, 1 duck, price 6s. , the property of
John Sibley
.

JOHN SIBLEY. I live at Hillingdon
, and am a labourer . - I keep ducks. On the 3d or April I was out - I had left my ducks safe.

WILLIAM NEIGHBOUR
. I live near Sibley, at Hillingdon. Between five and six o'clock on the evening of the 3d of April, I saw two ducks on the river - one was brown and the other white - they were not a quarter of a mile from Sibley's. I saw the prisoner come within about three hundred yards of me, and shoot the brown duck; he waded up to his knees in the water, and got it, put it into his pocket, and went away. I went and told Mr. Sibley, and the prisoner was taken next day - I am certain he is the man there was another man with him, but the prisoner carried the gun, concealed under his coat.

ELIZA SIBLEY
. On the 3d of April we had five ducks and a drake - one duck was a brown one - I missed that on this day. The river is across the field, about one hundred yards from the house; I have never seen the duck since. The prisoner lived at Uxbridge, and was taken the next day.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

812.
WILLIAM PURDY
,
HENRY DOWTY
, and
JOHN GRADY
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of March , 1 cask, value 3s., and 8 gallons of gin, value 3l. , the goods of
John Gyllyat Booth
, and
Felix Booth
.

JOHN PARKER
. I am clerk to Messrs. John Gyllyat,Booth and Felix Booth, they are rectifiers
, and live at No. 55, Cow Cross-street, Smithfield. On the 18th of March, about a quarter-past nine o'clock, I went with the waggon to Mr. Weller's, in Old-street - the carman,
Charles Merritt
, was with me - the waggon contained two pipes, one puncheon, one hogshead, and the cask, which was taken out, which contains eight gallons and three pints of gin, while we were racking off the two pipes for Mr. Weller, about a quarter before ten o'clock, I saw Purdy standing loitering about the waggon; he put his hand through the side of the waggon to assist me in pushing off the pipe, and his other hand on the horse-cloths; we finished the two pipes in Mr. Weller's, and made the waggon secure, as we thought, and went into the house to put on our clothes; when we had been in about five minutes, Buckle gave me information - I went out and ran in the direction he told me, and saw Dowty, whom I had not seen about the waggon, with the cask on his shoulder; I collared him with my left hand and took the cask with my right - I asked him where he was going to carry it; he threw it down, with an intention of throwing it on my feet; he said he was a porter and took casks or any thing for any one who asked him; Purdy was then on the opposite side of the way; and as soon as Dowty threw the cask down, Purdy ran away; I called Stop thief! the carman pursued him; I took Dowty to the watch-house, and Purdy was brought there in about two minutes - I am certain he is the man I saw about; I know nothing about Grady.

CHARLES MERRITT
. I am carman to Messrs. Booth. I saw Purdy waiting round the waggon all the time we were racking the gin; when we went in to put on our clothes some man came and gave an alarm; we ran out - I pursued Purdy, and saw Dowty carrying a cask of gin, which had been in the waggon; my partner came up to him and he threw it slap down almost on his goes - I pursued Purdy, because he ran way, and I thought he was as bad as the other - I knew him to be the man who had been waiting about the waggon.

JOHN BUCKLE
. I am a broker. I live near Mr. Weller. On the 18th of March I saw a waggon at his door, delivering spirits - I saw the three prisoners and another man with them - they had been waiting about at a distance, while the spirits were delivering; one of them was at the window of a cook's shop, and the other at the corner of Ironmonger-row; when the men were gone in to get their clothes, the fourth man, who is not here, nodded to the other three, and Grady got on the waggon-wheel and handed out the cask (which seemed to me to be a barrel of gin) to Dowty, who was waiting for it; Purdy stood at the door all the time - the other was still at the cook's-shop window, at the corner of New-street - Dowty went along Old-street, and up Ironmonger-row - I went and told the carmen of it - Dowty and Purdy were soon after brought to the watch-house.

Cross-examined by Mr. BRODRICK. Q. Where were you? A. At my own door, nearly opposite Mr. Weller's, fifty or sixty yards off; I live with my father, who is a broker - I saw the carmen go into the house to put on their clothes; I had been looking about for half-an hour - I was afraid to call out for fear they should knock me down; I did not make any alarm till the cask was gone.
COURT. Q. Are you quite sure Grady is the man? A. Yes.

JOHN PRIMETT
. I am a carpenter. I was coming through Old-street turnpike, and saw Purdy coming towards Golden-lane - I stopped him and gave him to the officer.

RICHARD VALENTINE HANDLEY
. I am a yeoman. On the 18th of March, about eleven o'clock, I was coming up Old-street, and I saw a waggon, belonging to Messrs. Booth, standing at the prosecutor's door - I was stopping to tie my shoe, and saw Grady lifting a cask from the waggon; he put it on the hind-wheel - another person came up, put it on his knot, and walked off with it - it struck me something was wrong, and I watched him; he went up Ironmonger-row; I heard the cry that they had been robbing a waggon; Parker ran up Old-street, and I up Ironmonger-row; Parker seized the man; and I saw him stretch himself up and throw the cask down, as if to throw it on his legs; I have not the least doubt it was Grady who handed the cask out, but I will not swear to him.
Cross-examined. Q. You had but a short time to see him? - A. No; I was examined before the Magistrate, and my belief was the same as it is now.

JOHN TWEEDY
. I am a constable. I was coming out of the watch-house when this happened; I saw some people running, and I put my prisoner back again; I saw Purdy run, pursued by another man; I pursued, and he was taken; I put him into the watch-house.

ROBERT LOCK
. I am an officer. I took Grady on Saturday evening, the 18th of March, about eight o'clock.
PURDY'S Defence. I happened to stop at the corner of a street, and heard the cry of Stop thief! I ran like other people, but never saw either of the prisoners before.
DOWTY's Defence. I was going down Old-street; a man asked me to carry a cask, and said he would pay me for it; I went to the waggon and took it; he told me to go on.
GRADY's Defence. The man has sworn falsely; he swore to me by having a blue coat and leather gaiters; when I was taken I had a blue coat on, but no gaiters.
COURT to BUCKLE. Q. What coloured coat had Grady? A. A blue coat and a pair of leather gaiters above the knee, and he had them on when he was in the watch-house.

ROBERT LOCK
. I do not think he had gaiters on when I took him; but I cannot swear he had not.

PURDY -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

DOWTY -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

GRADY -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

813.
CHARLES HUTTON
,
JAMES HANCOCK
, and
JOHN TAYLOR
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of March , 200lbs. weight of lead, value 3l., the goods of
Margaret Canham
, fixed to a certain building .

JOHN HEZEKIAH ESSEX
. I am a farmer, and live at Action. Margaret Canham is a widow and lives at Twickenham
- she has a lodge at the entrance of her premises - I saw the lead secure on the top of it about a fortnight previous to its being taken - I saw the same lead before the Magistrate but was not present when it was fitted.

WILLIAM HALL
. I am a constable. On the 10th of March, about half-past two o'clock, I saw Hutton going along Hounslow with a basket. Mrs. Hancock was close behind him - I followed him half a mile, and asked what he had got - he said some lead from Mr. Hancock's house, and he was going to Brentford to sell it - at the further end of Hounslow I got an officer, and we took Hutton - Mr. Emmerson and I went to Hancock, who is a shoemaker, and lives at the end of Hounslow - both the doors were fast - he went to the front door and I to the back; Mrs. Hancock said her husband was gone to Harlington, but a man said he had seen him just before - we then broke the door open and found him. I said to Hancock "You are my prisoner, you must go with me;" Emmerson went up stairs, and brought some lead, which Hancock said had been in Taylor's room; we asked where we could find Taylor; he said "If you go to Crawford-street, you will find him;" Emmerson went there and found him - we got a search-warrant a few days afterwards, and found some more lead in Taylor's box; as we were coming to London on the 11th, Hutton said "If we have taken the lead from Mrs. Canham's gate they can't swear to it now, because it is cut in pieces" - the other two prisoners were close to him, but made no observation. I believe they all lodged in Hancock's house.

JOHN EMMERSON
. I am a Bow-street patrol. We apprehended Hutton with the lead - we then went to the house, and I found four pieces more, which Hancock said was Taylor's - I found two more pieces in Taylor's box - I took them to the office, and took two or three tradesmen to see where the lead was taken from; the lead here produced matched exactly to the top of the building; I knew that Taylor lived at Hancock's, but I did not know what room he occupied; I heard Taylor say he knew the lead came into the house the same night it was lost off the lodge - there were 87lbs. of it.

DANIEL BERKSHIRE
. I am bailiff to Mrs. Canham. I saw this lead fitted on the building, and it matched exactly - I missed it on the 8th of March - I had seen it safe the day before.
HANCOCK's Defence. I let this man the room, and he had got the lead. I know nothing of him nor what was locked in his room.
HUTTON's Defence. Hancock asked if I had any thing to do - I said No; he asked me to carry it to Brentford for him.
NOT GUILTY .

814.
THOMAS PEARCE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of March , 15 yards of flannel, value 10s. , the goods of
John Fowke
.

JOB CLIFFORD
. I am shopman to Mr. John Fowke, a draper , in Oxford-street
. On the 14th of March, about three o'clock, a woman gave me information - I went out and found the prisoner about twenty yards from the door, with fifteen yards of flannel which had been standing within the door, surrounded by a chain.

THOMAS MORRIS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I am very sorry - I was rather in liquor.
GUILTY. Aged 73.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Months .

815.
JOHN MACQUIRE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of March , 2 pewter pots, value 2s. , the goods of
John Hinton
.

JOHN HINTON. I keep the Hare and Hounds public-house, St. John's-wood
. These pots are mine.

JAMES LAWS
. I am a shoemaker. I saw the prisoner in St. John's-wood-lane, about eleven o'clock, with two quart pots. about 190 yards from Mr. Hinton's house - he put them down, took them up again, then walked round to the back of a house, and got in at the window - I heard him beating something - I went up to the place, and saw him beating one of the pots with a brick; I said"What are you beating these pots for?" - he said he was going to take the other pot home; he went out at the front of the house; I called to a person, and had him secured.
Prisoner's Defence. I had been for a pot of beer, and brought it down to the gardener - I went into the building, and put the pots down, but I did not beat them.
GUILTY . Aged 50.
Confined One Month .

816.
THOMAS MALONEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of March , 1 pair of steps, value 5s. , the goods of
John Clough
.

GEORGE WADDINGTON
. I am a Bow-street patrol. Mr. Clough keeps an oil-shop , opposite Southampton-buildings
. On the 27th of March, about seven o'clock in the evening I saw the prisoner looking into his shop; there was a pair of steps at the window to keep the people from the paint - they were open, he closed them, and put them under the window - he then went a little way, returned, and took them up, and put them down again - then took them up and went away - I secured him.

JOHN PARTIGER
. I am porter to Mr. John Clough. I know these steps to be his.
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming down Holborn, very much intoxicated, and a man gave me part of a pot of beer to carry these steps over to Southampton street.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Confined Two Months .

817.
DAVID JENKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of February , 2 half-handkerchiefs, value 2s. , the goods of
Edward Harris
and
Thomas Harris
, the younger.

THOMAS ROBERTS
. I am an officer. On the 24th of February, about a quarter before seven o'clock, I saw the prisoner, and two other persons, at Messrs. Harris' shop - I saw him take the two half-handkerchiefs from the inside of the shop door, and put them into his pocket - I followed him, and took him about three or four yards from the door - Bertraun, who was with me, found them in his pocket - his companions did not go with him.

ANGELIOUS BERTRAUN
. I am an officer. I was in company with Roberts - I did not see the handkerchief taken, but I took the prisoner, and found the two half-handkerchiefs in his coat.

THOMAS HARRIS. I am in partnership with my fatherEdward Harris - we live in King-street, Soho
, at the corner of Hayes'-court - I know these handkerchiefs to be ours.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

818.
ROBERT JOHNSON alias ROBERT LAW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of April , 1 gown, value 10s. , the goods of
John Holt
.

JOHN HOLT. I keep the Duke's Head public-house, in Old Gravel-lane
. On the 1st of April, about a quarter before four o'clock, the prisoner and another came in - I served them with a pint of beer - they drank it, and gave me half-a-crown to give change; I sent my wife up stairs to get it, and in the mean time the prisoner went into the yard; my man had some suspicion, and missed the gown from the yard, where it hung just before - he followed the prisoner into the tap-room, and said, "He has taken something off the line in the yard" - I collared him, took off his hat, and found the gown in it - he said he was very sorry, and it was his first offence.

WILLIAM DIXON
. I am Holt's servant. I was in the kitchen when the prisoner went into the yard; I missed the gown - I followed him into the tap-room, and it was found in his hat.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I went backwards, and met a friend, who said, "Will you mind this gown for me."
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .
FIFTH DAY. TUESDAY, APRIL 11.
Middlesex Cases, Third Jury.
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

819.
THOMAS MASON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March , 1 shawl, value 1s., the goods of
Ellen Mullins
; and 1 jacket, value 2s. , the goods of
William Wilkinson
.

WILLIAM HALLETT
. I am a cow-keeper, and live in Tyson-street, Clerkenwell
. About half past five o'clock on the morning of the 24th of March, I went into my cow yard, and saw the prisoner coming out of one shed into the other, with a bundle under his arm: he turned into a stall where a chaff-engine was - he laid down his bundle there, went into another stall, and laid himself under the horse's head; I sent a man for the watchman, and the prisoner went into another stall; I then seat another man for a watchman; he attempted to make his escape, and I tried to seize him with one hand, having my light in the other, and some measures; he got from me, and ran to an open fence; I threw down what I had, and seized him by one leg; he then took a knife out of his pocket, and cut my two hands. One of the witnesses then came to me, and he cut at him in the legs; I tried to get the knife from him, but could not; he then cut at my legs, but with the back of the knife. I seized him by the throat - Ellen Mullins came, and got the knife from him - he was then taken to the watch-house - these articles were found in the manger.

WILLIAM WILKINSON
. I am in the service of Mr. Hallet. I saw the prisoner in a stall in his cow shed, on the 24th of March; I knew him very well. I went for the watchman. We found this jacket in the manger - he was quite sober.
ELLEN MULLINS. I go to Mr. Hallett's to get milk. - I had left this shawl there five minutes before five o'clock that morning.

THOMAS UNDERWOOD
. I am a constable. These articles were brought to me by Wilkinson.
Prisoner's Defence. I had been among the hay carts, trying to get some victuals. I got tipsy, and went to lay down in the manger, the shed being open.
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years . (See page 258).

802.
JOHN HITCHCOCK
,
JASPER HITCHCOCK
, and
ISRAEL DUNNING
were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April , 4 live same pigeons, price 20s. , the property of
Charles Wighton
.

CHARLES WIGHTON. I live in North-street, Poplar
. - I missed four pigeons about four o'clock on the morning of the 5th of April - I had seen them safe about seven o'clock the evening before; the pigeon' house is about thirty feet from my house, in my garden. I found it broken open, and four gone out of the seven, which I found at the watch-house.

JOSEPH CRUCE
. I am a watchman. About half-past two o'clock in the morning of the 5th of April, the three prisoners passed me in East India-road, and a little before three I heard a woman crying for the watchman - I ran to North-street, from whence the sound proceeded, and she told me there were three men getting on the leads at the top of the door; I ran after them, but did not see them. About half-past three o'clock I took (with some assistance) the three prisoners, whom I knew to be the persons I had seen at first; I found four pigeous on Jasper Hitchcock.

JAMES PURRY
. I am superintendant of the watch. - Cruce brought the prisoners to the watch-house; I found four pigeons on Jasper Hitchcock: I made inquiries, and found where they belonged to. I had seen the prisoners pass the watch-house just before three o'clock.
JOHN HITCHCOCK's Defence. I was going home to the Barking-road, over the iron bridge, where I work.
JASPER HITCHCOCK's Defence. I bought the pigeons on the Tuesday evening.
DUNNING's Defence. I was going to Blackwall-dock, to look for work. I never saw these young men before.

JOHN HITCHCOCK -
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined Six Months .

JASPER HITCHCOCK -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

DUNNING -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

821.
MARY LOCKET DREW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of April , two gowns, value 4s.; 8 yards of silk, value 1l. 8s.; and 1 handkerchief, value 2s. , the goods of
George Syredd
.

MARY SYREDD
. I am the wife of George Syredd - we live in Arlington-street, Clerkenwell
- we removed there three weeks ago; the prisoner and her husband were there at that time. On the 3d of April I missed a gown out of the drawer, which I had put it into, on the 30th ofMarch, and the prisoner saw me put it in - the silk was taken out of the one pair back-room.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. How do you know them? A. I am sure it is my gown by the pattern - I have since heard that all the prisoner and her husband had, was seized for 18s. - I believe they were in great distress, but I did not know it then.

WILLIAM CLUNES
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Liquor-pond-street. This gown was pawned by the prisoner in the name of Ann Parker, on the 31st of March.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you equally certain of her person before the Magistrate? A. Yes; I said it was a short dark woman, but I had forgotten her features - but the moment I saw her I knew her.

GEORGE STOWELL
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a gown which I took in pawn from the prisoner on the 3d of April.

WILLIAM BLACKBOURN
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a handkerchief which I took in pledge from the prisoner the 30th of March.
Prisoner's Defence. I had gone nine days without meat, and three days without bread - I have an infant six months old.
Three witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 24.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Fourteen Days .

822.
WILLIAM COOK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April , 1 plane, value 2s., and 1 jacket, value 2s. , the goods of
William Sharpe
.

WILLIAM SHARPE. I am a carpenter , and live in Burton-street. I had these tools in Wilson-street, Gray's-inn-lane
, on the 6th of April, when I went to breakfast; and when I returned they were missing.

WILLIAM WARD
. I am a bricklayer, and live next door to where William Sharpe was at work - Rogers came and told me to go into the house - I went, and met the prisoner coming over the back wall - I got over and held him till the officer came - I believe he was in great distress.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was quite in distress.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Confined Fourteen Days .

823.
WILLIAM BOWDLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of March , 1 coat, value 1l. , the goods of
John Ward
.

JOHN WARD. I am servant to Mr. Heath; I knew the prisoner and allowed him to sleep in the stable on the 8th of March; and on the 9th, I sent him to get some shears from Mr. Day - I gave him some money to pay for them; he brought me a message, in consequence of which I went to Mr. Day - when I returned he was gone and I missed the great coat off the bed.

Prisoner. He gave me the coat to pawn and gave me the ticket of another; he told me to get that, and to pawn this. Witness. There was a duplicate of another coat which he took away - upon my oath I did not give him the coat to pawn.

GEORGE KING
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Oxford-street. On the 9th of March the prisoner pawned this coat with me for 10s. - he then gave me a ticket of another coat, in the same name, John Ward - he took that one out and went away.

JOHN PEARMAN
. I met with the prisoner in a public-house, near Hyde-park-corner, on the 18th of March - he asked if I was out of service, and said he had two tickets, which he would sell for 5s. - they were of coats, which he bought at Ramsgate.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined Six Months .

824.
SAMUEL HEARN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of April , 1 pair of breeches, value 9s., and 1 hat, value 6d. , the goods of
David Davis
.
DAVID DAVIS. I am in the service of Mr. Sparke's, a cow-keeper. I lost a pair of breeches and a hat on the 1st of April - I had seen them safe at half-past seven o'clock the evening before.

WALTER OWEN HILLS
. I am a pawnbroker. This pair of breeches were pawned on the 1st of April, about nine o'clock in the evening, in the name of John Bennett, by the prisoner.

ELIZABETH JONES
. I bought this hat of the prisoner on the 1st of April, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening.

JAMES GRIBBLE
. I apprehended the prisoner. He told me he had sold the hat and pawned the breeches - he told me the places - he is well-known in our neighbourhood.

WILLIAM BARNET
. The prisoner asked me to go down with him and take the things - he gave them to me - I did not know they were stolen - he went and pawned the breeches and sold the hat.(Property produced and sworn to).
Prisoner. It was him who pawned the breeches - I took them and gave them to him.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

825.
WILLIAM BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of March , 1 book, value 3s. , the goods of
John Wilton
and
William Wilkins Wilton
.

WILLIAM WILKINS WILTON. I am a bookseller
, in partnership with my father, John Wilton, we live in High Holborn
. We lost a book, called "Humphrey Clinker," between seven and eight o'clock in the evening of the 6th of March - I was in the parlour, and a witness came and brought the prisoner in we searched him but could not find it- we took a light and looked in the yard just by our door and found the book.

JESSE PHILLIPS
. On the 6th of March I was passing, this shop and saw the prisoner and another young man - the prisoner took a book off a small shelf and put it into his trousers' pocket; I collared him and pushed him into the shop - we afterwards took a candle and I found the book about two yards from the place.
Prisoner. Q. You said there were three or four persons. A. No; you resisted, and turned to go up the gateway.

RICHARD GARDNER
. I was called to take the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I was standing near the window, with three or four other persons - as soon as the alarm was given they all ran away, and I stood still.

JURY to JESSE PHILLIPS. Q. Was it possible for the prisoner to have thrown the book up the gateway from where he stood? A. Yes, it was; the prosecutor had not missed it; there was a gas-light in the window, buthe took it him from under the board; I took hold of him immediately, but he turned his back and gave himself a twist round.
Prisoner. Q. Were not you standing in the gateway? A. No; I was not; I did not state so at Bow-street; I went up there, but did not see him throw the book.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

826.
JOHN BARNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of March , 1 sovereign , the money of
James Wright
.

JAMES WRIGHT. I am a sailor , and live in Hall's-rents, St. Catherine's. I went to a shop in Ratcliff-highway
, on the 28th of March; I saw the prisoner at the door, who asked me if I wanted to buy a suit of clothes or a jacket; I went in and bargained for one for 12s.; I put down a sovereign on the counter - he took it, put it towards his pocket, and kept it there a few minutes, when he threw down another, and said I had given him a counterfeit, and asked where I got it; I told him to put the jacket by, and I would call again when I got out - I looked at the sovereign, and it was not the one I gave him - it was whiter and lighter; I had taken two sovereigns of my Captain that day, and had changed one at Mr. Farmer's shop - they were both alike and of the same colour.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. How many shops had you been to? A. Only one; there was a young man with me, who is gone to sea; the prisoner came down the next morning after the officer had been for him; my Captain was before the Magistrate; there was a man and a woman in the shop; a man gave my shipmate the jacket, and he was putting it up.

WILLIAM WILSON
. I am an officer. The prisoner is shopman to Mr. Hart; he is not the owner of the shop; I went down to the shop, and the prisoner came to the office immediately.
NOT GUILTY .

827.
PATRICK JOSEPH CASHMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of March , 1 brass fender, value 1l. 15s. , the goods of
Joseph Adams
.

JAMES McGUIRE
. I am journeyman to Joseph Adams, ironmonger , St. Giles'. I was in the back of the shop on the 22d of March; the prisoner came in and asked if a person named Hobhouse worked there; I said No, and as he was going out he took this brass fender and put it on his shoulder; I took him and called my master down.(Property produced and sworn to).
Prisoner's Defence. A man asked me to carry a fender; I was very much intoxicated.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Confined Three Months .

828.
JOHN COWLEY
and
THOMAS FOSTER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of March , 75lbs. weight of flour, value 13s. , the goods of
William Aldridge
.

WILLIAM ALDRIDGE. I am a baker , and live in Coppice-row, Clerkenwell
. The prisoner Foster was in my service; on the 28th of March two persons came from the watch-house, and asked if I had lost any flour - they had some in a bag; the bag was not mine, but the flour was; it had been in my flour-house which opens by a flap into the street; I missed 80lbs. of flour out of a sack which was full the night before.

Prisoner FOSTER. My master told me to put some fresh and some old flour into the bin; I had not enough to make my dough, and I took that out of the sack. Witness. No, there was enough without opening that at all; he wanted about 80lbs. to make his dough - there was enough of the other flour which I saw in the trough; I can tell within a peck; I saw the flour at the watch-house, and it was precisely the same as that in the sack.

JOSEPH ROOT
. I am a watchman of Clerkenwell. I was going to get a light of the next watchman, and met Cowley coming up Pear-tree-court, about three hundred yards from Mr. Aldridge's, with a bag on his shoulder - I called twice to know what he had got, but he gave no answer - I went up and said, "What have you got here?" he put it down, and said he found it; I said, "You must go to the watch-house, and take the flour;" he said he would not - I called another watchman - we secured him.

Prisoner COWLEY. Q. Did I not say I had picked it up? A. No; you did not stop till I put my hand on it - you then pointed to a corner which I had passed two or three times just before, and said you had found it there.

THOMAS GARNER
. I am the watch-house keeper. Cowley was brought there about one o'clock on the 28th of March, with a bag of flour, and when I went out I knocked at Mr. Aldridge's cellar, and asked if he was there; I was told by Foster, (to the best of my belief,) that he was not - I left word that some flour was found, and was at the watch-house, and if he came there he might see it; I think the answer I received was, "Very well;" after Mr. Aldridge was up I went to his house again - he came and saw the flour, which he said he believed was his - he then searched over his flour and missed it; he inquired what house Cowley belonged to, and he said the Marquis of Gransby, which was the same house his man belonged to.

COURT to
WILLIAM ALDRIDGE
. Q. Who did you leave in the cellar? A. Only Foster - he was to remain there, and call me up at three o'clock, which he did, but did not say any one had been inquiring for me; I have a sample from the sack, and it corresponds with this.

JAMES PERRIN
. I am a baker. I have compared the flour that was found with that in the sack, and they appear to me to be both the same.

JOHN BOWYER
. I received the sack of flour from the witness and gave it to Mr. Garner.
FOSTER's Defence. This man is quite a stranger to me; he does not belong to the house of call to which I do; Mr. Aldridge is not the only gentleman who has the same sort of flour.

COURT to WILLIAM ALDRIDGE. Q. Do you know any thing about Cowley? A. They both used one house, and I have heard that he and my man were about together; I do not think Foster would have wanted any flour to make up the dough, but if he did, it could not be near the quantity missing; I am certain there was nearly, if not quite, enough - I can tell within a peck.

COWLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 43.

FOSTER.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years .

829.
WILLIAM CARRINGTON
was indicted for
feloniously entering, on the 12th of March , a garden, and taking 3 trees, value 3s., and 6 plants, value 2s. , the property of
William Carrington
.

The prosecutor's name being
Joseph Edwards
, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

830.
ANN CALNAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of March , 2 half-crowns , the monies of
John Thomas
.

SARAH THOMAS
. I am the wife of John Thomas, a green-grocer - we live in Ratcliff-highway
. On Sunday, the 26th of March, there were three half-crowns in my till, and a great deal more silver; I left the shop about ten o'clock, for about a minute, and when I returned I saw the prisoner in the shop - I had seen him on the Sunday before - the till was open; I said, "I believe you are the little girl who robbed me last week;" I put my hand on her shoulder, and drew out the till, and said, "You little hussey, you have robbed me again;" she had her hand clenched, which I opened, and found in it two half-crowns; I had taken half a crown a few minutes before.

CHARLES TICKLE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and bring the money.
GUILTY. Aged 10.

Judgment Respited
.

831.
CHARLES CURRIE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of April , 20 yards of stair carpet, value 35s. , the goods of
George Chowles
.

GEORGE CHOWLES. I live in North Audley-street, and am an upholsterer . On the 1st of April, about eleven o'clock, I went to Bayswater, and while there I received information - I came to town, and missed these three pieces of carpet, which are mine.

JOHN LEWIS
. I am a Bow-street patrol. Between twelve and one o'clock, on the 1st of April, I saw the prisoner in Brook-street, about half a mile from Mr. Chowles'; he had the carpeting concealed - when I came up to him he dropped it and ran - there was another boy with him, who ran another way.

RICHARD BOWDEN
. I saw the officer throw down this carpet by my door.

Prisoner's Defence. I went down the street - a young man came up to me, and said he would give me sixpence to take it to Bond-street - he rested it on the post, and the officer came and asked what I had got - I said I did not know - he said, "Who does it belong to?" I said, "That young man;" he ran away, and the officer after him - I then thought he had not come by it honestly, and I ran off.
Mr. CROWLES re-examined. I had left three painters in the shop.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

832.
JAMES CARTY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of March , 1 coat, value 30s. , the goods of
George Biddlecomb
.

GEORGE BIDDLECOMB. I am a butcher , and live at Twickenham. I drove my cart to Cavendish-square
on the 30th of March, and left my coat on the seat of the cart, while I went into a gentleman's house - I returned in about three minutes and missed it - I drove on, and in St. Giles' I saw the prisoner walking with my coat on - I got out, took hold of him, and said it belonged to me; he said he picked it up in the street.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up.
GUILTY . Aged 53.
Confined Three Months .

833.
ELIZABETH NICHOLLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of February , 1 bed, value 1l. 15s.; 2 blankets, value 5s.; 1 pillow, value 2s., and 1 pillow case, value 6d., the goods of
Charles Jones
, in a lodging room .

JANE JONES
. I am the wife of Charles Jones - we live in Little Union-street, St. George's, East
. I let a furnished room to the prisoner at 5s. a week - she had not completed her week; I went out to work on the 2d of February, and came home about half-past eight o'clock at night - she was gone, and I missed this property; she never returned to pay the rent; I am quite sure of her person - I do not know how she gets her living.

Prisoner. She was perfectly aware that I pawned the things, and I gave her part of the money. Witness. I knew nothing about her pawning the things, and never gave her leave to do it; she had been in the house with a lodger of mine, for a few weeks before she lived with me.

JOHN FIELD
. I am foreman to a pawnbroker, in High-street, Shadwell. I took in a bed of the prisoner, to the best of my recollection, on the 1st of February, on which there was 5s. more advanced the day after.(Bed produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I gave her part of the money towards the rent - another person took the room besides me; I had left the room, but the other person was there.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Transported for Seven Years .

834.
ELEANOR RYAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of March , 1 silver thimble, value 1s., and 1 earring value 1s. , the goods of
Amelia Mills
, widow , her mistress.

AMELIA MILLS. I am a widow, and live in Titchfield-street
. The prisoner was my servant - I had an officer to search her, and he found on her a thimble and an earring, which I had seen about a fortnight before in my kitchen-drawer - I had accused her of taking them - she said nothing.

WILLIAM REED
. I am an officer. I searched the prisoner, and found a thimble and a gold ear-ring, which the prosecutor said were her's; the prisoner said she brought them with her.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I found the thimble on the floor - I put it into my pocket and forgot it - my mistress said she had lost the ear-ring for three years.
GUILTY. Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .

835.
THOMAS RAWLINS
,
JOHN PRITCHARD
, and
CATHERINE DONOVAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of March , 1 watch, value 4l.; 2 seals, value 3l.; 1 ring, value 10s.; 1 watch chain, value 1s.; 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; 1 pair of scissars, value 1s., and 1 knife, value 1s., the goods of
Charles Tanner
, from his person .
Mr. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

CHARLES TANNER. I am an independent gentleman . - On Easter Tuesday, the 28th of March, I spent the evening with some friends - I was rather forward in liquor, and met the prisoner Donovan in Oxford-street, near St. Giles's - she invited me home with her, and I went, not knowing where she was going to take me - I had not much judgment. She took me to Bainbridge-street, St. Giles's
, as I afterwards found - we went into a back room up one pair of stairs, and it was agreed that I was to pass the night there. I undressed, and she took off her gown, but was very slow in getting her things off. I had two purses in my side pocket, containing silver and gold, and to the best of my recollection, I had a watch; I am certain I had had it two hours before. I cannot say but what it might have been extracted from my pocket before - I had come from the City, and had been walking about; I had a blue cotton handkerchief in my pocket. The prisoner then said I should give her the money before we went to bed, but I was quite unwilling to remain, from the appearance of the place, which was very mean and shocking - I said I would go away; she then said she would have some money, but I was unwilling to show where my purses were, as my clothes were off, and on a chair; I therefore declined giving her any at that time; she then sat down on a chair, took up the coat, and searched the hinder pockets; she threw the coat about several times, but did not discover the purses; she arose up again, and said if I would not give her some money she would soon call in some person who should make me - she then went outside the door, and instantly Pritchard came in; I had not heard her say anything outside the door. She came and stood on one side of me, quite close - he stood on the other - she began telling him that I would not give her any money - at that moment Rawlins came in at a window - they both stood by me, but said nothing. Donovan then took up the poker, held it over my head, and said she would dash my brains out, unless she had some money; she then struck me with her first under my right ear; I saw I had better concede to any thing then lose my life. I told her my property was in my waistcoat pocket; she then went back to the table, snatched up the waistcoat, and blew out the candle; they then all three went away with my waistcoat. I put on my clothes as fast as I could, went out, and called the watchman, Ryan - he went with me up to the room, and found nothing there. I described them to him - as we were going up the stairs I found my pocket handkerchief. We then went three or four houses off, up to the second floor - he knocked at the door, and said, "Let me in;" they said, "Who is there?" and I think it was the woman, who said, "We are all in bed;" the watchman said if they did not let him in he would burst the door open - the door was then opened; my waistcoat was laying on the table; the three prisoners were in bed together, and another woman, who is not here - Ryan and the other watchman made them all get up - Donovan was quite dressed, as when she left me; I believe the men had their coats off. I am certain the waistcoat was the one she took from the room.
Prisoner DONOVAN. Q. Did not you tell me I might take the waistcoat, and did I not take two letters and two small keys out of it, and say I would go and get a light? A. No.

TIMOTHY RYAN
. I am a watchman. On the 28th of March I saw Donovan come into the street, between one and two o'clock - and in the course of ten minutes afterwards she came out with a candle, and asked me for a light, which I gave her; she then went back into Jones'-court. I was going down Bainbridge-street between two and three o'clock, and the prosecutor said, "I am robbed by a girl and two men;" I went with him to the room, and found nothing there - I told him to be silent, as I had seen the girl come out of No. 6, and he had come out of No. 10. I got the next watchman, and went to No. 6 - I found the handkerchief on the stairs; I went up, and told them to open the door; one said, No, the door was locked, and what did I want - I said they must open the door - some one did so; we entered, and the three prisoners and another woman were in bed together - Donovan was dressed, and the others had their clothes off, except their shifts and shirts. The prosecutor said, "I can swear that is the girl, and these are the men;" he had described them before. I found this waistcoat on the table.

MORRIS LEONARD
. I was called to assist Ryan - he has stated what is correct.(Waistcoat and Handkerchief produced and sworn to.)
DONOVAN'S Defence. These two young men are innocent. I never saw them till I went up into their room.

RAWLINS' Defence. I was in bed about twelve o'clock- about three I heard a knock; Donovan came in, and asked for a light; I said there was no light and no fire; she had not been there many minutes before she heard footsteps on the stairs; she appeared very confused, and ran to the bed - the door was only on the latch.
RAWLINS - GUILTY. Aged 18.
PRITCHARD - GUILTY. Aged 16.
DONOVAN - GUILTY. Aged 18.

Of
stealing, but not from the person .
Transported for Seven Years .

836.
ELEANOR NIHILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of March , 11 spoons, value 20s.; 2 gowns, value 4s.; 2 shawls, value 6s.; 1 pelisse, value 3s.; and 5 caps, value 3s., the goods of
John Hovee
, her master .

SARAH HOVEE
. I am the wife of John Hovee, and live at the Repository, in Goswell-street
; the prisoner had been with us a fortnight. On the 8th of March, I rang the bell, about half-past six o'clock, for her to get up - she did not answer, and I went up to her room and found she was gone - I came down and found the front door open - I missed all this property - I saw her in custody, about twelve o'clock that day.

WILLIAM DUFFIELD
. I am stable-man to Mr. Hovee. I met the prisoner in Chiswell-street, about twelve o'clock- I told her her master and mistress were out after her - she offered me something in a handkerchief, which I would not take - but a young man, who was with me, took it home, and I detained her.

RICHARD FIELD
. I was with Duffield. The prisoner said I might have the things if I would let her go - I took them, and left him in charge of her - there were some articles in the handkerchief.

JOHN WILLIAM HARRISON
. I took the prisoner. Onthe 8th of March, about 12 o'clock; Mr. Hovee delivered four table-spoons and tea spoons to me - the prisoner had a gown, a cap, and a shawl on her person - and she told me if I would go to Long-alley, I should find some more - I did so, and found more in Sweet-apple-court, and the other tea-spoons at a pawnbroker's.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 17.
Recommended to Mercy .
Transported for Seven Years .

837.
ELIZABETH BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of March , 1 watch, value 30s., the goods of
James Forbes
, from his person .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

838.
EDWARD CLARK SPENCER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of March , 1 pair of sheets, value 2s.; 1 shirt, value 4s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 6d.; 2 towels, value 6d.; 1 night cap, value 2d., and 1 apron, value 6d., the goods of
George Kent
, from the person of
William Kent
.

ELIZABETH KENT
. I live by Stepney church. On the 13th of March, about twelve o'clock, I sent my grandson, William Kent, with a bundle, containing these articles, to take about two hundred yards, to his mother's, to be washed - he returned and told me they were gone.

WILLIAM KENT. I am eight years and a half old. My grandmother sent me with a bundle to my mother's for the things to be washed; the prisoner met me, and asked me to go down Globe-lane
to get two bundles of silk; and said, he would hold my bundle - I gave it to him - and when I came back he was gone.

WILLIAM MOGRIDGE
. I am an officer. I was walking down Mile-end-road, and saw the prisoner running across the field with a bundle - I pursued, and took him near Stepney church - he said he had met his own mother in Whitechapel-road, and she gave him the bundle.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence, (written). I was persuaded by
Charles Gigg
, a neighbour, to go to a bull-hunt - as we were in the road, he said "There is a boy with a bundle, we will frighten him" - he told me to send him for two skeins of silk and hold his bundle the while - and when I had it, Gigg ran away and told me to follow - I became alarmed, and asked him to take the bundle - but he said two men were following us.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Whipped and Discharged.

839.
ELEANOR SHEA
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of March , 1 bag, value 1d.; 1 snuff-box, value 6d.; 19 sovereigns, and 2 half-sovereigns, the property of
William Hanington
, from his person .

WILLIAM HANINGTON. I keep a public-house in George-street, Grovernor-square. I was at the Red Lion, public-house, Duke-street, Manchester-square, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening of the 12th of March - I was a good deal the worse for liquor, and happened to go in there, when I saw the prisoner, whom I had known for upwards of twenty years - she once kept a house near me; she was drinking with another person, named Ryan, who had a little girl with her - I spoke to the prisoner, and gave her something to drink; I went home with them to their room in Gee's-court, Oxford-street
- I should think it was between ten and eleven o'clock, but I am not certain; we had some more to drink there; I believe the little girl went out for liquor, but I am not certain; I went to sleep on the floor, and about half-past four in the morning, I awoke; I went out into the passage to go home - I missed my bag, with nineteen sovereigns, and two half-sovereigns, and requested them to give it me; I did not miss my snuff-box till afterwards; I went to their house; I changed something out of it after I met them at the public-house - it was in my left-hand breeches pocket - when I asked them for it they both laughed at me; the watchman happened to be going by and I called him - he found the snuff-box in the room, and the officer found the bag on the Monday following.

CATHERINE RYAN
. I am the daughter of
Johanna Ryan
- she lives in Gee's-court - the prisoner was an acquaintance of hers. I am in the workhouse - I was at the public-house, and saw the prosecutor come in, and have some gin and water; he did not speak to the prisoner, but she took hold of his glass and drank out of it - my mother and I went home, leaving them there; when we had been at home about an hour, they came there together - the prosecutor sent me out for half a pint of rum, which they drank; they then sent for half a gallon of beer; I went out for another half pint of rum, and afterwards I saw the prisoner pull up her clothes, and dance before the prosecutor; my mother said she ought to be ashamed of herself, and then she sat upon his knee for a quarter of an hour; we had not much candle - the prosecutor then got up to go away, but he fell down on the floor, and soon afterwards the candle went out - I then went to bed - when I awoke in the morning the prisoner and my mother were laughing at the prosecutor; I then went and sat on the stairs - the prosecutor called the watchman - he could not open the door, and the watchman broke in - he got another watchman, and they searched, but could not find the money - they went to the watch-house.

COURT. Q. Do you recollect any thing about a watch? A. Yes; the prisoner went up to the prosecutor, and pulout his watch - she said "By G-d he has got a good watch," and then put it in again - she then went to his other side, and took out a bag of sovereigns - he awoke, and said "What are you at?" he then pushed it into his pocket again, and she went and sat down on the bed - I then went to sleep, and did not see any more - the candle went out.

WILLIAM VARNDILE
. I am a watchman. I was calling the hour of half-past three, and heard a great noise - I came on towards the passage, and heard a rustling - I said "Who is there?" and this gentleman said "It is I;" I said "Open the door;" he said "I can't;" I then told him where the bolt was, and we got it open; I went in and took the prisoner - I found a half-sovereign, four shillings, four sixpences, and four-pence halfpenny, on her; the half-sovereign she took from some part of her clothes, on her right breast - she had before said she had no money about her.

THOMAS HENDERSON
. I am a watchman. I searched Ryan, and found on her a half-sovereign, six shillings, andfive-pence halfpenny, the prosecutor's snuff-box, and the key of his watch.

THOMAS PERRING
. I was serjeant of the night. I was standing in Oxford-street, when the watchman came to me, and said a person was robbed at No. 6, Gee's-court; the prosecutor said he had lost upwards of twenty sovereigns - the prisoner said she had a shilling or two, and a few halfpence - she was then searched, and I saw her take something from her right breast, which I could not get from her hand.

Prisoner. Q. Did not I say I took that from my duplicates? Witness. No; you was in liquor. I then went back to the room, and on turning the ashes up we pulled out the bag, with nineteen sovereigns and two half-sovereigns in it.

ROBERT WILLIAMS
. I am an officer. I went with Henderson, and found this bag, with nineteen sovereigns and two half-sovereigns in it.

WILLIAM HANINGTON
. This is my bag - here is a piece of the same cotton it is made of.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating, that she had met Ryan at the public-house, and, being intoxicated, stopped at her house all night, and was asleep when the robbery was committed.
GUILTY . Aged 50.
Transported for Seven Years .

840.
LOUISA PHILLIPS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of February , 3 sovereigns, the money of
William Pelpford
, from his person .

WILLIAM PELPFORD. I am an excavator . I fell in with the prisoner in the City-road between twelve and one o'clock on the 26th of February; I had been drinking pretty freely, and had about nine sovereigns; I went home with her to a house in Wellington-place
; I asked what I was to give her; she said 1s. 6d.; I took a sovereign out, and laid it on the table, and said "I will have my money taken care of before I have any thing to do with you;" I then pulled out two sovereigns, she snatched them out of my hand, and ran down stairs; I ran after her, but was stopped in the passage by a girl or two, and a young man; she escaped, but was taken the next night; I am certain she is the same girl - she was a stranger.

FRANCIS LEONARD
. I am a watchman. I heard a great disturbance on my beat, and a call for Watchman! the prisoner ran by me; I did not stop her because I thought there was something serious up the court; I then met the prosecutor, who said he had been robbed; I told him I knew her, and should see her again.

Prisoner's Defence. I met the man; he would go home with me, and followed me to the door, and came in; I said"What do you want here;" he said "Do you think I have no money" - he took out three sovereigns and threw them down on the table; I said were they for me - he said Yes; after being in the room some time, because I would not give them to him, he called the watchman.
NOT GUILTY .

841.
DENNIS KELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of February , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
Thomas Russell Drury
, from his person .

THOMAS RUSSELL DRURY. I am a printer , and live in the Strand. On the 24th of February, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, I was in Long-acre
, walking with my sister; I felt my handkerchief taken from my pocket, and turned round immediately; I saw the prisoner attempting to pass me with it in his hand; I collared him, and he threw it down by the door of a wine vaults - my sister picked it up.

ISAAC SAYER
. I am an officer. I have the handkerchief, and took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to).
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

842.
GILES SUSSEX
was indicted for
embezzlement .

JAMES GARRETT
. I a toy manufacturer , and live at Hoxton, in the parish of St. Leonard's, Shoreditch. The prisoner had been in my service fourteen or fifteen months - he carried out goods and received money, which he was to return - he was paid weekly; I sent him on the 14th of February to Mr. Clementson with some goods, and to receive the money; David Evans went with him; I did not see him again till I saw him at Worship-street Office; he had given me no notice of leaving; he should have accounted to me for the money as soon as he returned; he had a basket and truck with him.

WILLIAM CLEMENTSON
. I am a newsman and dealer in toys. I deal with the last witness; the prisoner brought some toys to me on the 14th of February; I paid him ten sovereigns and a ten pound note; Evans and him were together; I have the number of the note which I gave him.

DAVID EVANS
. I went with the prisoner to Mr. Clementson's; I saw him pay the prisoner in ten sovereigns and a 10l. note - after we had delivered the goods we went to have some refreshment - he left me in a public-house, and said he would go and get a bit of good old Cheshire cheese, and I saw him no more.

ROBERT TURLE
. I keep the Three Tuns public-house in Bridgewater-square. The prisoner came there on the 14th of February, and had some liquor - he returned again in the evening with a woman, and they staid till I was about to shut up the house; I was given to understand he had some money about him, and said if he liked to leave it with me he would know where to find it; he left me a 10l. note, and called again two days afterwards and had two sovereigns out of it, and ordered a leg of mutton to be cooked; I gave Vann 5l. 15s. 6d., which was the balance - the note was paid to a butcher, and then to a person in Smithfield.

THOMAS FAIRCHILD
. I gave ten sovereigns for the note, and paid it away.

THOMAS VANN
. I received information from the prosecutor, and found the prisoner at the public-house - Mr. Turle said he had left the note with him.
Prisoner's Defence. When I drink a drop I do not know what I do.
GUILTY . Aged 63.
Confined One Year .

843.
JOHN WHEATLEY
was indicted for
bigamy .

HENRY FELSTED
. I am a vellum-binder. I work for Mr. Thomas, in Cornhill - my sister Elizabeth married the prisoner in 1809, at St. Olave, Southwark - I was present and saw them married; I signed the register - he was then a shoemaker - my sister had been in service and lefther place to marry him; he lived with her about six months, when she was so ill-treated that she left him and went to service, because he would not support her; she died at the end of last July.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Did not your sister change her name? A. Yes; while she was in service she took the name of Groves: Mr. Groves was a tailor- he is dead I believe; they lived together as man and wife about seven years.

ELIZABETH ANN ROGERS
. The prisoner married me on the 20th of October, 1823, at St. Matthew's, Bethnalgreen. I had been in service, and left it to marry him - I had known him from the July before; I had no fortune; he behaved very far from well to me - I was never happy - we had no children; no one told me to bring forward this case, but I heard he had another wife.

Cross-examined. Q. Is your mother here? A. Yes; I recollect the prisoner going to the police-office with my mother - it was to inquire whether his wife was dead; he said he had not seen her for nine years; I had no suspicion that he was married when I married him.

JAMES LEA
. I am an officer, of Lambeth-street. I produce the certificates of the marriages and a burial.

These certificates were here read, the first was of a marriage between
John Wheatley
and
Elizabeth Felsted
, on the 17th of May, 1809, at St. Olave, Southwark - and the second of John Wheatley and Ann Rogers, on the 20th of October, 1823 ; also a certificate of the burial of Elizabeth Groves, at St. Mary-le-bone, on the 1st of August, 1825.

- ROGERS. I went with the prisoner to Worship-street, before he married my daughter Ann; he came to my house as a single man - but he was accused of being married - he said he had been, but his wife was dead, he believed, and he would go and inquire whether he might marry again; there was no Magistrate there, and the clerk would not decide the question, but said he might advertise his wife.
GUILTY. Aged 35.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury .
Confined Six Months .

844.
JAMES BLAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 1 saw, value 5s. the goods of
Nathaniel Hudson
.

NATHANIAL HUDSON. I am a carpenter . On the 16th of February I left my saw in Black-horse-fields
, on the carcass of a house, at twelve o'clock, and missed it at one.

JOSPEH HARROW
. I am a bricklayer. About ten minutes past twelve o'clock I was on the top of a building, and saw the prisoner coming along with the saw wrapped up in a dirty cloth, about a quarter of a mile from where it was taken - I called to him, and asked him how he got it - he said he had found it; I said, "If you will go back, and can show the place, you shall be let go;" he went back, put it against a heap of bricks, and said he had found it there.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I met a boy who asked me to take care of this saw for him.
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Transported for Seven Years .

845.
JOHN BARRATT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of March , 60lbs. weight of lead, value 20s., the goods of
John Smith
and
William Hill Stamp
, and fixed to a certain building .

ROBERT BOYD
. I am a builder. I know where this lead was taken from - I afterwards saw it fitted - it tallied exactly; I have no doubt it came from there - the building belongs to John Smith and William Hill Stamp; on the 22d of March, about a quarter-past eight o'clock, I saw the prisoner and another person drawing a sack from the area of this carcass, and when they got it to the wall joining the side of the bank, I saw another youth heaving it on the prisoner's back; I pursued, and met him with the lead - the other escaped; the lead was gone from off the gutters of four houses - there were seven or eight hundred weight in all.

HUGH CRAIG
. I am an upholsterer. I saw the prisoner draw the bag from the area - I was not aware what was in it; I called Boyd, who followed him; I turned the bag out, which contained the lead.

ROBERT TEASDALE
. I am watch-house keeper. The prisoner and the lead were brought to me; I saw it fitted on the building, and it matched exactly.

JOHN SMITH
. I am part owner of this property, in trust for Mr.
Joseph Biddulph
.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

846.
JONATHAN BATTY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of March , 1 cast-iron plate, value 5s.; 1 door-scraper, value 2s.; 1 dung-fork, value 2s.; 1 pewter plate, value 1s., and 1 brass cock, value 1s. , the goods of
Thomas Heapley
.

THOMAS HEAPLEY. I live in St. John's-wood-road
. About nine o'clock in the morning of the 3d of March, I was in the first floor of my house - the child came to say two boys had got over the wall - I ran down stairs with my son and desired him to get over the wall and see what they were about - he got over and called me - I jumped over and saw the prisoner and another, who had got these things, which had been taken from the back of my garden, into the field - I had seen them safe forty-eight hours before, but they were not on the spot where I found them twenty-four hours before - the prisoner fell on his knees, and hoped I would forgive him - he said it was the first time he ever was found taking any thing.

JOHN HEAPLEY
. I saw the prisoner and another boy breaking up a cast-iron gutter - I gave the alarm, and went down and found the property over the wall - the prisoner and the other were carrying it - I heard him beg forgiveness.

ROBERT WILLIAMS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner. GUILTY. Aged 15.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Judgment Respited
.

847.
JOHN BARRY
and
WILLIAM JONES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of March , 2 pairs of stockings, value 4s. , the goods of
John Sansom
.

JOHN SANSOM. I live in Brick-lane, Whitechapel
, and am a hosier . On the 15th of March the prisoner Jones came to my shop, with another man, and while they were looking at some ribbed worsted stockings, Barry came in; they did not seem to know one another. Barry asked to look at some caps, gloves, and stockings, which wereshown him - he took his hat off, and put it on the counter to try a cap on, I believe - my wife was serving him; Jones and the other were looking at a variety of things. I kept my eye closely upon them; I afterwards saw Barry put his hat upon his head - he had bought one pair of lamb's-wool stockings and a cap, and paid for them; the others agreed for a pair of stockings, paid 6d. on them, and left them - Mr. Davies came in, and told Barry, who was going away, to take off his hat, and two pairs of these stockings were found in it - he first said they must have got in without his knowledge, and then he said one pair was his own, but I knew they were mine; he had what he had bought in his hand. Jones and the other were very near him.

SIMON DAVIDS
. I live near Sansom. The prisoners came to my shop to purchase a waistcoat - they gave me a great deal of trouble, and at last Barry offered me money which I would not take; they went away. The other man, who is not here, came in afterwards, and agreed for one - he told me to put it away for him. After they were gone I missed a new waistcoat - I suspected Barry, as he had taken his hat off two or three times. I went and found him in Sansom's shop.
BARRY'S Defence. I bought them.

BARRY -
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Confined Six Months .

JONES -
NOT GUILTY .

848.
MARY CREED
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of March , 2 gowns, value 8s.; 2 sheets, value 7s., and 2 shifts, value 3s. , the goods of
Thomas Innell
.

MARTHA INNELL
. I am the wife of Thomas Innell - he lives at No. 5, Peter's-lane, Cow-cross
. On the 18th of March the prisoner came to assist me, and to turn my mangle; she staid two or three hours, and about three hours after she was gone I missed a bundle, containing the articles stated in the indictment.

JOHN REEVE
. I am a pawnbroker. I have two gowns and a shift, pawned by the prisoner, on the 28th of March.

JOHN CROSS
. I am a pawnbroker. I have two sheets, pawned, I believe, by the prisoner, on the 18th of March.

JOHN LOADSMAN
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner; she had one of the shifts on.

GEORGE WADDINGTON
. I went to Mrs. Cross', where I found the prisoner in bed - I think her mother has led her into it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 14.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .

849.
JOSEPH DUNN
and
CHARLES DUNN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of March , 6 yards of bed furniture, value 8s.; 2 shirts, value 24s.; 1 tablecloth, value 8s., and 4 handkerchiefs, value 4s. , the goods of
Thomas William Charles Edwards
.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS WILLIAM CHARLES EDWARDS. I live at Homerton
. I employed Ann Hand to wash for me. On Monday, the 20th of March, I had occasion to go into the garden, while the clothes were hanging out, and about a quarter before seven o'clock I went into the garden again, when one of the lines was cut and gone; I had given Hand my bed furniture to wash.

ANN HAND
. I was employed on the 20th of March, to wash for this gentleman; there was one line, which contained four half-handkerchiefs, a small window curtain, two of master's linen shirts, the bed furniture, and a large table-cloth. I had seen them all safe about half-past six o'clock, when I went for a pail of water; my master called me about seven, and the line was cut at each end, and the things all gone. The line was fourteen yards long; I can swear to the bed furniture - I had separated it for the purpose of being washed, and it corresponds exactly.

WILLIAM COWLING
. I am a constable of Hackney. - On the 25th of March I apprehended the two prisoners - I did not search them, but Attfield did.

WILLIAM ATTFIELD
. I was with the constable. I searched Joseph Dunn on the 25th of March, about eleven o'clock in the morning, at Hackney, and found this bed furniture, quite wet, wrapped round his body, under his clothes. I asked how he came by it, and he said it was his own - that he had had it washed, and was going to sell it to his brother, at Clapton, as he was very much in want of money, and if any body else could own it he must suffer for it. Garton (who was with me) found this piece of print, which appears to be the same furniture, in the hat of Charles Dunn; I did not hear what he said about it.

CHARLES DUNN'S Defence. As I was coming home I met a watchman in the field, and coming over the fields I saw something white in a dry ditch; I took it home, and showed it to my landlady. On the Sunday some persons came in, and said I had better take it to the first public-house, nearest to where I found it; I was going the next morning to take it to the White Horse public-house, and while I was there Mr. Attfield took my brother; I went with them, and at Worship-street I pulled off my hat, and he saw what was in it.

JOSEPH DUNN -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

CHARLES DUNN -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

850.
JAMES PERRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of March , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of a certain man, whose name is unknown, from his person .

JAMES HILL
. I am a copper-plate printer, and live in Greek-street, Soho. On the 30th of March, about three o'clock in the afternoon, I was in St. Martin's-lane
; I had come through the church-yard; I saw the prisoner and two others, following a gentleman very closely - the prisoner took a handkerchief from his pocket, and threw it to one of his companions - another person followed his companion, and he threw it into a bookseller's shop, and then ran into a pawnbroker's - we called out, and the shopman came out - we said he was in the shop, and he went and pulled him out; we were going with him to the watch-house, when the prisoner came up with a stick, and said "That is the b-r; rescue the prisoner, and kill him;" he struck me on the head, which stunned me, and he got away - the gentleman who lost the handkerchief, was gone, and we have never seen him.

WILLIAM PICKET
. I work at Mr. Vicker's, in Regent-street. As I was coming down Hemmings-row, on Thursday, the 30th of March, about three o'clock, I heard a cry of Stop thief! the prisoner got off, but the one who had the handkerchief, ran on, and threw it into a bookseller's shop; a man, who pursued him, brought it out again - he ran into Mr. Lorton's, the pawnbroker's, and his nephew pulled him out again - we then went into Green-street, where we met the prisoner with a stick, who said "Rescue the prisoner; and kill him;" the prisoner then got away, but the officer came up, and he was taken afterwards.

WILLIAM YOUNG
. I am a police-officer of Bow-street. I took charge of the prisoner, and have had the handkerchief - the owner has not been found.

Prisoner's Defence. On Saturday the 1st of April, the man I work with, came and called for me as he was going to Covent Garden; I had not been out from the Monday before; on Saturday, the 1st of April, I came down to get some milk, and my little sister was with me; they were taking some prisoners to Westminster-hall, and I stood to look at them - an officer, who is not here, told me to stand there, which I did about five minutes - he brought another person and asked if it was me - he said Yes, and they took me into a public-house, and asked me if I knew the boy they had given two months to - I said No.

COURT to
JAMES HILL
. Q. How soon after you received the blow was the prisoner taken? A. After the other was up at the office.

ANN JOHNSON
. I live at No. 3, Union-place, Orchard-street, Westminster. From Tuesday last to Thursday last the prisoner was in my room making a pigeon-house; I am quite certain of it - his mother gave him the wood - he had taken medicine, which caused him to be rather ill; he went to his mother after he left me - he lives at home with his mother - he left me about seven o'clock on Thursday last.
JAMES HILL re-examined. This was on Thursday week, the 30th of March.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Life .
Middlesex Cases, Fourth Jury, Before Mr. Common Serjeant.

856.
TRIPHEMA BARTHOLOMEW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , at Paddington, 1 sheet, value 4s.; 1 table-cloth, value 2s., and 1 blanket, value 5s., the goods of
William Daniels
, in a lodging-room, in his dwelling-house, against the statute .

WILLIAM DANIELS. I live in Bray-street, Paddington
. The prisoner came to lodge at my house on the 16th of February - the articles stated were let with the room; she remained with me till the 2d of March - I then gave her notice to quit; when she went she took the key of the room-door, and a bonnet belonging to my wife; I got an officer to open the door, and missed the articles.

THOMAS PROBERT
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in the Edgware-road. I took a blanket in pledge of the prisoner - I have a sheet and table-cloth - the ticket for the sheet is my writing; I do not know who pawned them.(Property produced and sworn to.)

MICHAEL MORRIS
. I am an officer. I produce the duplicates of the blanket which I found in the prisoner's room.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

857.
JAMES GAYTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of March , 19 yards of printed cotton, value 10s. , the goods of
William Spooner
.

WILLIAM SPOONER. I am a linen-draper , and live in Chiswell-street
. On the 21st of March I saw this print outside the rail, about one o'clock, and about a quarter before two I was informed it was gone.

THOMAS MENDHAM
. I am an assistant to Mr. Lazarus. On Thursday the 21st of March, I was in his shop, which is opposite Mr. Spooner's, and saw the prisoner trying to lift the print from the iron where it hung - he had a companion; he then passed up the street, and in a short time returned and handled it again - I turned round to answer a question, and on turning my head again I saw it was gone - I ran out and pursued the prisoner, who took the right hand turning of Finsbury-square - I called, Stop thief! and he dropped the print from his apron - I took it up, and followed; I lost sight of him, but he was stopped, and I brought him back.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me drop the print? A. I did not actually see you, as I stumbled at the time - I was about fifty yards from you.

JAMES BEDLARE
. I am a watchmaker. On Thursday, the 21st of March, between ten and eleven o'clock, I saw the prisoner and another at Spooner's door, and two or three hours afterwards I saw him in custody.

SAMUEL BRIDGES
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner a few minutes after two o'clock.
Prisoner's Defence. I have a witness here who saw me at home at the time; one witness said it was Wednesday, and two that it was Thursday.
NOT GUILTY .

858.
JANE HANNAH LAYFIED
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of March , 3 yards of toilenette, value 5s. , the goods of
James Christmas
.

JAMES CHRISTMAS. I am a tailor , and live Whitechapel-road
. I missed some toilenette on Monday, which I had seen safe on Saturday the 10th of March; the prisoner was afterwards apprehended; I told her she was the last person who should have robbed me; she said she did take it - McGrath shewed me a pawnbroker's shop kept by Howse, where I found it.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN VANN
. I am an officer. The prosecutor applied to me to take the prisoner - on the 28th of March I went to her house, and took her - as we were going to the watch-house she said she hoped Mr. Christmas would forgive her.

MARY McGRATH
. I live in Size-yard, Whitechapel. The prisoner called for me to go to the other end of the town; I was not ready - she told me to come on to Aldgate-church - she came there to me and then left me, and went down the Minories, and came with a bundle, which she said was a black silk gown - she went on to a pawnbroker's and told me to wait; I looked in at the window and saw the toilenet there - she then came out and said she could not get enough for it - she pawned it at the corner of a coach yard in St. Giles' - she came out and said, thank God she was rid of her black silk gown.

JOHN HARRISON
. I am an officer. I went to Mr. Christmas and got a piece of toilenette; I then went to a pawnbroker in St. Giles's, and compared it with this - it corresponded exactly - it was pawned at Mr. Howse's, but he could not swear to the person.

COURT to
MARY McGRATH
. Q. Did you say you went into the shop? A. No; I saw it on the counter - Ishowed the shop to Mr. Christmas - it is opposite the church.
GUILTY . Aged 49.
Confined Three Months .

885.
ELIZABETH PETTY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of March , 1 saw, value 1s. 6d., and 1 mallet, value 1s. , the goods of
Henry Scott
.

HENRY SCOTT. I am a carpenter , and live in Great Saffron-hill
. On the 26th of March I went out about four o'clock, and returned about eight - my room door was open and my tools gone.

THOMAS THOMPSON
. About seven o'clock in the evening of Easter Tuesday I was in Golden-lane, and saw the prisoner offering these articles for sale at a broker's shop; I asked whose they were - she said her husband's; I asked if there were any marks on them - she said No, but I found some and took her into custody.(Property produced and sworn to).

Prisoner's Defence. I met a woman in Gray's-inn-lane, she was bleeding, and said she had parted from her husband - she took me to this house - I engaged to sleep there that night - and in the morning, as I came down stairs, my foot struck against these things - I offered them for sale in Golden lane.
GUILTY . Aged 49.
Confined One Month .

852.
GEORGE WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of March , 7 metal weights, value 30s. , the goods of
Joseph Hammersley
.
JOSEPH HAMMERSLEY. I am a brass turner , and live in Clerkenwell-close. On the night of the 14th of March I lost my weights; and next morning the watchman produced them.

ROBERT PRITCHARD
. On Tuesday, the 14th of March, about ten minutes before twelve o'clock at night, I was going down Pear-tree-court, and saw the prisoner loitering about, and knowing there had been a robbery opposite, I went down and asked who he was waiting for - he said I person named Crawley - I had lived there three or four years, and never heard of such a name - I detained him till my son got the watchman - he was taken to the watch-house, where he pulled out the weights - three out of his jacket pocket, and four out of his hat.

ROBERT LOOK
. I apprehended a prisoner, who is not here now, about eight or nine o'clock at night; I know he and the prisoner were in company together.

Prisoner. Q. He stated before the Magistate that the clock was striking nine? Q. I did not; I was at the sign of the Duke of Gloucester public-house, and saw the prisoner come in with a man named Caton.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 16.

853.
THOMAS WILKINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of February , 1 pair of stays, value 14s. , the goods of
Frederick Wright Cook
.

ELIZABETH VENTOM
. I am in the employ of Frederick Wright Cook, of Oxford-street
, a stay-maker .
