On the 25th of February, about half-past eight o'clock in the evening, I was at work in his shop, and heard a rattle at a pane of glass which had been broken, and over which a paper was placed - I heard the cry of Stop thief! I then missed a pair of stays from the window - I went to the watch-house, and the prisoner was there - the stays were brought in soon afterwards - there were two pieces of paper at the window pinned together - and one of them had been pushed in.(Property produced and sworn to.)

THOMAS ROBERTS
. About half-past eight o'clock I was with Bertraun, in Oxford-street, and saw the prisoner with another person; the prisoner took the stays from the window, and gave them to his companion - they ran across Woodstock-street - Bertraun followed them, crying Stop thief? the prisoner threw down the stays, and I saw him stopped by a watchman. I went with Bertraun to a doctor's to take a mad-dog - I then went to the watch-house, and saw the prisoner - I am certain he was the person.

ANGELIOUS BERTRAUN
. I was with Foster, and saw the prisoner, and another lad, at the window; I did not see the stays taken, but I saw the other put them under his coat - they crossed over, and I ran after them, towards Shepherd-street - I saw the man throw the stays down.

JOSEPH CASLADE
. I heard the cry of Stop thief! and saw the prisoner run across Oxford-street, and down Chapel-place, where I took him.
Prisoner's Defence. I was running down the street, - the gentleman stopped me, and the watchman came and took me.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Three Months .

854.
WILLIAM ORANGE
and
JOHN JOHNSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of March , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
William Thomas Brough
, from his person .

WILLIAM THOMAS BROUGH. I am a tailor , and live in Bartholomew-close. This handkerchief is mine - I lost it between Finsbury-square
and Whitecross-street
- I had seen it ten minutes before.

WILLIAM BOLTON
. I am a constable. I was going into Whitecross-street, and saw the two prisoners following four gentlemen - I saw Orange soon after come round a waggon, with this handkerchief in his hand - I caught hold of him, and took up the handkerchief, which he threw under the waggon - I could not see that Mr. Brough was one of the gentlemen they were following.

JOHN FOWELL
. I was in Whitecross-street, and saw them - I saw Orange take the handkerchief out of Mr. Brough's pocket, and put it into his bosom half way - he ran into the road; Bolton took him, and he threw it under the waggon; I did not see Johnson do any thing.
ORANGE'S Defence. I came up to a waggon, and I ran to get out of the way.
JOHNSON'S Defence. I was running by a coach, and a waggon was coming in - the officer took hold of me, and said I had been with Orange, but I had not seen him do any thing.

ORANGE -
GUILTY .
Whipped and Discharged.

JOHNSON -
NOT GUILTY .

855.
ESAU SPENCER
and
CATHERINE WOOD SPENCER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of February , 1 watch, value 2l.; 4 seals, value 1l., and 1watch-key, value 2s., the goods of
William Bleading
, from his person .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

856.
JOHN ERBY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of March , 8 bushels of oats, chaff, and beans, mixed, value 30s., the goods of
William Waterhouse
and
Joseph Waterhouse
, his masters .

JOSEPH WATERHOUSE. I am in partnership with my father, William Waterhouse - we keep the Swan with Two Necks, Lad-lane
. The prisoner was driver of one of our corn vans - he was sent on the 8th of March with this property. I have a list of where he was to leave it.

JAMES CONSTABLE
. I was employed by Messrs. Waterhouse, at Brook-street, near Brentford. On the 8th of March the prisoner left me four sacks of mixed corn - he should have left me five; I told him there was one short; he said his master had no more corn in the yard, and he would bring six on the Wednesday afterwards, but on that day he brought but four; I told him I should send his master word of it - he said I might send and be d-d; he appeared to be drunk on the 15th, but on the 8th he said it was all right enough about the corn.

JOHN FIELDING
. I am horse-keeper to Messrs. Waterhouse, at Brentford. The prisoner should have brought me four sacks on the 8th of March, and he brought but three.

JOHN PROSSER
. I am landlord of the Harry public-house, Mile-end. The prisoner called at my house several times.

SAMUEL JOHNSON
. I am granary-man in the service of Messrs. Waterhouse. I gave the prisoner twenty-seven sacks on the 8th of March - he was to take eighteen to Roam's stable, near Romford, five to Brook-street, and four to Brentwood.

WILLIAM MORGAN
. I am an officer. I took up the prisoner, and as he was going along Holborn he said he was afraid he should be sent to Newgate, for William Middleton had enticed him to do it, and he had but 3s. out of the 12s., and he was a great fool for doing it - that he had sold the two sacks for 6s. a sack.
Prisoner. I was drawn into it by the horse-keeper at the Harry; he asked me a great many times before I would do it, and said he would let me in at the back gate.
GUILTY. Aged 33.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor, having had a good character .
Confined Three Months .

857.
WILLIAM SEARLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of January , 1 bed, value 25s.; 2 pillows, value 3s.; 1 pillow-case, value 1s., and 1 sheet, value 2s., the goods of
Mary Poulton
, widow , in a lodging-room .

MARY POULTON. I am a widow, and live in Union-buildings, Leather-lane
. The prisoner came at the latter end of October, to lodge with me, and left on the 21st of January, without notice - I went into the room, and found a note, with some duplicates of the property stated in the indictment.

FRANCIS RAMSAY
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a feather bed and blanket, pawned by a female.

MICHAEL OSBOURNE
. I am a pawnbroker. I have some articles pawned by a female.

WILLIAM JORDAN
. I apprehended the prisoner about a month ago. I asked if he knew a person of the name of Poulton - he said, "I know what it is about - it is about the bed and other things - it was poverty made me do it, but I have now got a service, and shall soon be able to redeem them" - he had hardly a thing to cover him.
GUILTY. Aged 22.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

858.
GEORGE PAYNE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of March , 5 handkerchiefs, value 20s., and 1 shawl, value 20s., the goods of
Charles Cleverly
and
James Hutcheson
, his masters .
CHARLES CLEVERLY. I am in partnership with James Hutcheson - we live in Chiswell-street; the prisoner was in our service.

WILLIAM HAYES
. I am a pawnbroker. These handkerchiefs were brought to me by the prisoner, on the 11th of March - he said he bought them at Gravesend of Mr. Hurley - I detained him - he made great resistance.

THOMAS GARDNER
. I am a constable, and took him in charge. I found the shawl in his coat pocket.(Property produced and sworn to).
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY. Aged 22.

Strongly recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Eight Days .

859.
JOHN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 99 yards of Canvass, value 3l. 10s. , the goods of
Benjamin Gawthorne
.

HENRY CLAYTON
. I am an apprentice to Benjamin Gawthorne, who lives in Great Portman-street. About a quarter before eight o'clock, last Friday night, I was told a person was walking up and down, and I supposed they were after the canvass - I stopped, and watched the prisoner, who was at the shop, and saw him take this canvass, and walk off with it - I pursued him - a person met him and turned him round - I then took him.

HENRY STOWELL
. I took the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. It was laying against a baker's shop - the witness came out - I asked if the property belonged to her - "Yes," says he - "Then take it," says I.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Confined Two Months .

860.
MARIA PEARMAN
,
ELIZABETH MAYWOOD
, and
ANN SUMMERS
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of March , 1 coat, value 3l.; 1 gown, value 14s., and 2 handkerchiefs, value 6s. , the goods of
William Hughes
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

861.
WILLIAM MANNING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of March , 25 bushels of soot, value 18s. , the goods of
Robert Wiltshire
.
The prosecutor did appear. NOT GUILTY .

862.
WILLIAM KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of March , 1 coat, value 15s. , the goods of
Benjamin Hart
.

BENJAMIN HART. I am a slopseller , and live in Rosemary-lane; the prisoner was my shopman . I received information from Greenwood - and accused him of taking a coat - he said he had taken it to the Black Dog public-house, in Denmark-street, to raffle - he asked me, the night before, if he should take it, and I said No, as he was addicted to drinking.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you propose to me to take it on the Monday evening to have it raffled for? A. No; I declined it.

BOYD SILVESTER
. I am an officer. I found the coat in the possession of the prisoner's wife.

JOHN GREENWOOD
. I am shop-boy to Mr. Hart - I saw the prisoner take the coat - he said he was going to take it, but did not say where.
Prisoner. Q. What were the words I said to you? A. You said "John, I am going to take this coat;" I told the Magistrate you said it was to raffle for.
NOT GUILTY .

863.
THOMAS HUSSEY
and
WILLIAM THOMPSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of April , 1 knife-case, value 2s.; 23 knives, value 10s., and 25 forks, value 8s. , the goods of
Edmund Horsefall
.

EDMUND HORSEFALL. I live in Gloucester-place, Camden-town
. This knife-case, knives, and forks, are mine; I saw them safe on Saturday morning last, when I opened the window - the servant left the door open while she went for a pail of water - a man came in and took them; I was in the kitchen, and saw him go out with his hat on.

JOHN BOSTON
. I am a porter, and live in Henry-street, Hampstead-road. About half-past nine o'clock on the morning of the 8th of April, I saw the two prisoners and two other persons - I watched and saw Thompson go to Mr. Horsefall's, No. 11, Gloucester-place - he had nothing when he went in, but he came out with a mahogany case before him - I raised a cry and he handed it to Hussey, who turned a corner, but they were pursued; I helped to secure Hussey in a house into which he had run - he was making his escape out of the back door.

GEORGE MACHIN
. I saw the witness in Camden-town last Saturday, about half-past nine o'clock - he called to Mr. Davis, the tobacconist, next door, and called me - I ran out - I saw Hussey lay down the knife-case, and I took it up - he then turned a corner - I did not see Thompson.

ABRAHAM LORIMER
. I am an officer. - I got the case of knives from Machin - I shewed it to Mr. Horsefall, who claimed it.(Property produced and sworn to.)

HUSSEY'S Defence. I was going up the road, and I met two young men, who asked me to carry it for them, and said they would give me 2s. - they went into the house, brought it out, and gave it me; when I heard the cry of Stop thief! I put it down and ran.
THOMPSON'S Defence. I was about half a mile from the place - the man who took me came, and said his house had been robbed, and he did not know but I might be one of them.

HUSSEY -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

THOMPSON -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

864.
ANN FITZHENRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April , 1 half-crown, 13 shillings, and 6 sixpences, the goods of
Thomas Ashton
, from his person .

THOMAS ASHTON. I was in Holborn
last Friday night, about eight o'clock; the prisoner caught hold of me, and asked where I was going - I said home; she put her hand into my waistcoat pocket, and took out my money, which I had seen a quarter of an hour before - I caught hold of her and gave her to the watchman. I was quite sober.

JAMES SULLIVAN
. I am a watchman. I heard the cry of Watch! and I went out of my box - a gentleman, who was going away, said he saw the prisoner put her hand into the prosecutor's pocket - I took her to the watch-house, and found on her thirteen shillings, six sixpences, and half-a-crown - she said she had 1l. 11s. 6d., which her husband gave her.
Prisoner's Defence. I had the money in my pocket - it was my own - the watch-house-keeper's wife told the prosecutor not to come in in such an indecent condition.

JAMES SULLIVAN
. No; there is not a word of truth in it - the prisoner was rather drunk but knew what she was about.
JURY to THOMAS ASHTON. Q. Do you always carry your money in your waistcoat pocket? A. I had a hole in my trousers pocket - I had a sixpence more in my pocket- she took it all at one time.
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Seven Years .

865.
BENJAMIN BLOUNT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of March , 1 plough-plane, value 5s. , the goods of
Thomas Pope
.

THOMAS POPE. I am a carpenter . I was at work with the prisoner at Mr. Irbert's yard, Forum-street, Berkeley-square
; I had a plough-plane in a box there, and lost it on the 23d of March; I asked the prisoner if he had seen it - he said he had not.

JOHN LUCAS
. I live in Rochester-row, Westminster-bridge. The prisoner lodged with me about thirteen weeks - he brought a plough to my house, about a fortnight before he was taken; he said he brought it because he took one from me and pawned it, and brought that instead - he said he went into Forum-street, Berkeley-square, to borrow it for me - I said it was not so good as mine; I gave it to Hopkins.

JAMES LLOYD HOPKINS
. I am an officer. I have the plough.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 45.
Confined One Month .

866.
GEORGE PARKER
and
JAMES PARKER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
James Shilcott
, from his person .

JAMES SHILCOTT. I am a servant . I was at the Opera-house door on Thursday, the 6th of April, and saw the two prisoners together, just behind me - I put my hand to my pocket, and missed my handkerchief - they were taken into custody about two minutes afterwards, and I saw the handkerchief taken from George Parker's bosom; I had felt it safe five minutes before.
Cross-examined by Mr. CRESWELL. Q. Were there many other persons about? A. Yes; but the prisoners were talking together.

SAMUEL WELLS
. I was at the Opera-house. The prosecutor told me he had lost his handkerchief, and I found it on George Parker.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GEORGE PARKER's Defence. My brother had nothing to do with it - I picked it up.
Five witnesses gave the prisoners a good character.

GEORGE PARKER -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined One Month .

JAMES PARKER. -
NOT GUILTY .

867.
GEORGE CLARKE
,
JAMES CLARKE
, and
THOMAS BRANSCOMB
were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of April , 2 live tame ducks, price 5s. , the property of
John Dixon
.

JAMES DIXON. I am a glass-cutter , and live in Park-place, Hare-street-fields
. On Saturday last I had two live ducks, which slept under the stairs at night, and they run out in the morning - I saw them safe at half-past six o'clock in the morning; I received information, and about one o'clock in the day I saw the prisoners eating some pastry, and supposed they had sold the ducks, and got the money to buy it; I asked George Clarke about them, and he said he had not seen them - he was a neighbour; I looked into his basket, and saw the dung of the duck - he had seen me before I came up to him, and told James Clarke to run away; James afterwards told me he had sold them to a Mr. Clarke, in Montague-street; I went there and got them - I know them to be mine.

CHARLES BARRY
. I am a butcher. I was near the prosecutor's house on Saturday last, about seven o'clock in the morning, and saw four boys pinning the ducks up in a corner against the house - George Clarke then caught one and put it into a basket - one of the others caught the other, but I cannot say which - I told a woman of it.

ISAAC CLARK
. I am a poulterer, and live in Old Montague-street. On Saturday morning, about eight o'clock, George Clarke brought the ducks to me, and said they were his own, and that he lived opposite Mr. Wells, the farrier - I gave him half a crown for them; I put them into my yard till the prosecutor came.

ISAIAH BANBURY
. I was coming from my own home a little before eight o'clock, and I saw George Clarke with two ducks - and a man, whom the last witness employs at times looked at them, and the witness asked, out at the window, what price they were, and the boy said, "Half a Crown, "and that he lived at No. 5, Charles-street, opposite Mr. Wells, the farrier; I afterwards saw Joseph Clarke, near the door of the Compasses, public-house, with some silver in his hand, and a fourth boy was near him; they went to several places to get change - I saw some halfpence in their hands, and they were gone in a moment.

ROBERT WOOD
. I am an officer. I bring the ducks, which I got from Clarke's - he would not give them up till I went to get a summons - then he gave them up.
BRANSCOMB's Defence. I was asleep on Saturday morning, and George came and called me about half-past six o'clock, and I went with him.
GEORGE CLARKE - GUILTY. Aged 15.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Whipped and Discharged.

JOSEPH CLARKE. -
NOT GUILTY .

BRANSCOMB. -
NOT GUILTY .
SIXTH DAY. WEDNESDAY, APRIL 12.
London Cases, First Jury.
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

868.
JAMES PAYNE alias JOHN BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of February , 1 wrapper, value 6d., and 20 yards of woollen cloth, value 15l. , the goods
Zachary Langton
and others, his partners.

HENRY BATTEN
. I am clerk in the employ of Messers. Pickford and Co. I received a truss from the Angel Inn, Fleet-market, on Thursday, the 23d of February, directed to
Joshua Lever
, Bolton, Lancashire; we were to convey it to Manchester.

JAMES POWNER
. I am clerk to Messrs. Pickford. On the evening of the 23d of February I was in the office, at the Castle Inn, Wood-street, and saw the prisoner come off the shafts of a waggon, with a truss on his shoulder - it was going to the City basin, and was directed to James Lever, Bolton. I followed him, and stopped him in Wood-street; the truss fell and I fell - he ran away; I followed, and called Stop thief! I saw him in a few minutes, and have no doubt of him.

THOMAS DAVIS
. I am in the employ of Messrs. Pickford and Co. I loaded a truss on their waggon in the yard on the 23d of February, about half-past ten o'clock; on the fore part of it - it was directed to Joshua Lever, Bolton, Lancashire.

JAMES GREIVES
. On this evening I was at my door, opposite the gateway. I heard the cry of Stop thief! ran out, and saw the truss in the street; I took it up - the witness ran after the prisoner, down Love-lane, and in a minute afterwards I saw him brought back.

JAMES HARRISON
. I work for Messrs. Pickford. I saw Grieves take the truss up, and brought it to the office while the prisoner was in the yard.

JOHN BARNES
. I am a constable. I received the prisoner and this truss.

JAMES POWNER
. This is the truss - it is the property of Messrs. Pickford and Co - Zachary Langton is one of their partners.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

869.
STEPHEN KEY
and
JOHN JONES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of March , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Richard Cleobury
, from his person .

RICHARD CLEOBURY. On the evening of the 31st of March, I was in Queen-street, Cheapside
- I had a yellow silk handkerchief in my pocket - I saw the two prisoners with another person - Girton came to me, and asked if I had lost one - the two prisoners went to the right, and the other to the left.

THOMAS GIRTON
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoners at the end of Sweeting's-alley - I followed them to Queen's-street, and saw them follow MR. Cleobury; about half-way down the street key picked his pocket of a handkerchief - the other was close to him, and Jones was behind, but close together - I followed them till they crossed the street - I went to Mr. Cleobury and told him - I then followed the prisoners and took them - the third one did not stay with them a minute after it was done -the prisoners had three handkerchiefs; but not Mr. Cleobury's.
Cross-examined. Q. You saw the man pick the pocket and did not touch him? - A. No; he did not go quite one hundred yards.
JONES's Defence. There was a man playing music - I went down the street to hear it, and met Key there - Mr. Cleobury came with the officer, and they took us.
NOT GUILTY .

870.
JOHN WATKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of February , 53lbs. of cheese, value 35s. , the goods of
George Fitch
and
Thomas Fitch
.

GEORGE FITCH. I am in partnership with my brother Thomas, we are cheesemongers
, and live in Leadenhall-street
- this cheese is ours - it was on a pile near the door.

JAMES DODD
. I am in the prosecutor's service. On the 28th of February I missed something from the door; I went out and saw the prisoner with the cheese under his left arm - I called Stop thief! - he dropped it and ran with all speed; I pursued him till the officer stopped him; I had seen this cheese safe about half an hour before.
The prisoner put in a written defences stating that Dodd, at the time, could not identify him, but said he thought him the man.
JAMES DODD re-examined. I am sure he is the man who dropped the cheese; I lost sight of him as he turned round by the five lamps, and was taken in Fenchurch-street.
GUILTY. Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Fourteen Days .

871.
SUSAN JAMESON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of March , 2 half-crowns, 6 shillings, and 2 sixpences, the monies of
Benjamin Fish
, from his person .

BENJAMIN FISH. On the 26th of March I was in Little Moor-fields
, between twelve and one o'clock at night, and saw the prisoner; she said "Young man, I want to speak to you, come down this little alley;" we staid there some time, and as soon as she was gone I missed my money from my right hand trousers' pocket; I had unbuttoned my trousers; I did not give her any money - she was taken to the watch-house in about ten minutes - my purse was left in my pocket and two sixpences in it - six shillings were taken from the prisoner's bosom, and a sixpence from her mouth; I had been drinking, but was perfectly aware I had lost my money.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you give me 6s.? A. No; none at all.

JOSEPH HORTON
. I am a constable. I found five shillings and two sixpences in the prisoner's breast - I asked her if that was all she had got - she said Yes; but I thought she talked rather thick, and found two half-crowns and one shillings in her mouth - the prosecutor had stated that his money was 12s., in half-crowns, shillings, and sixpences.
NOT GUILTY .

872.
ANN WILKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of March , 1 lace cap, value 6s. , the goods of
James Edwards
.

JAMES EDWARDS. I lost a lace cap on the 14th of March, from my front room on the first floor. I was sitting in the back room and heard a noise; I went into the room - I saw the prisoner - I asked what she did there - my wife came in and missed the cap - I sent for an officer, but before he came she pulled the cap out of her pocket, put it on her head, and said it fitted her very well - she was in liquor.

SARAH EDWARDS
. I went into the room, and the prisoner took this cap from her pocket.
GUILTY . Aged 45.
Confined Two Months .

873.
JOHN SAVAGE
was indicted for
stealing on the 23d of February , 1 cask, value 8s., and 8 gallons of Cloves cordial, value 3l. 16s. , the goods of
John Gillyatt Booth
, and another, his partner.

JOSEPH SMITH
. I am servant to Messrs. John Gillyatt Booth, and his partner - they live in Cow-cross-street. On the 23d of February, I was in White-cross-street
- I went up a yard, and left my waggon with some casks in it; I came back, and saw a man in the waggon, who gave the prisoner a cask out, and ran away; the prisoner went down Whitecross-street, with the cask on his shoulder - he walked as fast as he could, and I stopped him - he brought the cask back - it contained eight gallons of cloves cordial.

JACOB COHEN
. I saw the prisoner with the cask - he said he had to carry it to Smithfield for sixpence.

JOSEPH HORTON
. I am a constable. I was coming down Whitecross-street and saw a number of people - the witness had hold of the prisoner by the collar - I took charge of him.
Prisoner's Defence. I was employed to take it to Smithfield.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

874.
LYDIA LEGGETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of January , 111/4 yards of thread-lace, value 4l. 6s.; 3 yards of blond-lace, value 3s.; 3 yards of ribbon, value 1s. 6d.; 61/4 yards of muslin trimming, value 5s. 2d.; 2 bands of work, value 2s.; 1 garnet, ring, value 1s., and 1 ivory fan, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Elizabeth Dimes
, spinster , her mistress.

ELIZABETH DIMES. I am single and keep a show-room in John-street, Bedford-row. The prisoner was my servant , and had access to my property - I had not missed any thing but the ring and the blond-lace.

Cross-examined by Mr. LAW. Q. Where did you live at the time? A. I lived part of the time in Chapel-street; I found part of my property at Mr. Arthur's, in Bird-in-hand-court, Cheapside; the fan and trimming were found in a box which she had bought of me before she left, and some were found under her bed; there are still many things missing, which I have not found.

SUSANNAH DOCKER
. I was in the prosecutrix's service. I went with her to the room in Bird-in-hand-court - the ring and blond lace were in a small box under the prisoner's bed.
Cross-examined. Q. Was this at Mrs. Arthur's? A. Yes; the prisoner had no character when she came, but a sister of her's lived with Miss Dimes - she went from there to Mr. Arthur's.

THOMAS DIMES
. I was present when the articles werefound - the prisoner was protesting that she had nothing more but what she had given up - these things were found in the room afterwards - when the fan was produced she asked if my sister could swear to it.

REST KNIGHT
. I am an officer. I was sent for, and took the prisoner with the property.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 22.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Six Months .

875.
WILLIAM PRITCHARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 1 copper can, value 3s., and 1 pewter quart pot, value 1s. , the goods of
John Marshall
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

876.
ABRAHAM BATES
and
WILLIAM BRIGGS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of March , 1 handkerchief, value 3s. the goods of
David Richardson
, from his person .

DAVID RICHARDSON
. I was in Leadenhall-street on the 8th of March, and a person told me my pocket was picked; I missed this handkerchief, which I had safe two minutes before.

ROBERT HESKETH
. I was in Leadenhall-street on the 8th of March, and saw the two prisoners near the prosecutor - Briggs drew the handkerchief from his pocket, and handed it to the other; it was then thrown on the ground - I secured them, and called to the prosecutor. I found a watch on Bates.
BATES' Defence. I saw this young man passing a cart, and the officer came and said I had taken the handkerchief.
BRIGGS' Defence. I had not had the handkerchief.

BATES -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

BRIGGS -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

877.
WILLIAM ADAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of March , 65 pieces of printed paper, value 1s. 2d.; 296 wood-cuts, value 4s. 8d.; 150 copper-plate impressions, value 5s.; 70 printed books, value 11s. 8d.; 3 printed books, value 3s.; 13 books, value 2s., and 86 other printed books, value 16s. 8d. , the goods of
John Cumberland
, his master.

SAMUEL TURNER
. I am a constable. Mr. Cumberland desired me, on the 18th of March, to go to his warehouse in Blackfriars
; the prisoner came out, and I stopped him - I took him to a yard opposite, and searched him - I found these covers in his hat, and these wood-cuts. I took him to the Compter, and them went with Mr. Cumberland to his lodging, where we found some copper-plates, cuts, and other things. When I took them out of his hat I asked what they were - he said waste paper, and he wanted to paper his room with them - I asked if his master allowed him waste paper, and he said No.

TERENCE TIERNEY
. I am a bookseller, and live at the corner of Rossell-court, Drury-lane. Some of Dolby's Plays were brought to me by a female, whom I have seen since at Guildhall - she told me her name was Shields.

WILLIAM WELKER
. I am a bookseller. Between the 10th and 17th of March, a woman brought some books to my house - I saw her at Guildhall; she said there that she was the prisoner's wife; he was present, and did not deny it.

HENRY YORKE BRACE
. I am a bookseller. Twenty-six of Dolby's Plays were brought to me on the 10th of March, by a woman, who appears since to be the prisoner's wife; she came to me again, and I gave information to the prosecutor.

JOHN CUMBERLAND
. I live on Ludgate-hill, and am a bookseller - I have a warehouse in Play-house-yard, and the prisoner was my warehouse-man , and had the whole care of that warehouse. I received some information, and employed an officer to watch his proceedings. On the 18th of March I went with the officer to Play-house-yard, and remained at some distance, while he took the prisoner down a gate way, to search him - these articles are all mine - I never gave him any perquisites. I can swear to these Percy Aneedotes, by a blank place being left for the name.

Prisoner. Q. Were not a great number of these plates and books lying under foot in the warehouse for any one to take? A. No; I employed you to take them to the warehouse, and put them away - they are now in a course of sale, and have been so these four or five years.
GUILTY . Aged 43.
Transported for Seven Years .

878.
FREDERICK EDWARDS
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Louisa Rankins
, on the 18th of March , putting her in fear, and taking from her person and against her will, 2 shillings , her monies.

LOUISA RANKINS. I am single . On the evening of the 18th of March I saw the prisoner in Holborn, and went with him to a house in Gloucester-court
- we were both very much in liquor - we went into a bed room, but I did not go to bed, because I did not wish it; I do not know whether I was on the bed or not, nor whether he did any thing to me or no - the landlord came up while he was there, and I believe the prisoner struck me; I lost a tooth but I do not know who gave me the blow; I had some money in my hand, which was taken or knocked out, but I do not know who did it - the watchman came in at the time, but I do not know whether the prisoner did any thing when he came - we were both quite drunk.

ROBERT EVANS
. I am a watchman. I was called to this house by a female; I found the prisoner and the prosecutrix in the two-pair back room - her mouth was bleeding very much - she was crying; I was informed, by a female, that the man had been beating this girl - she said"He has robbed me, as well as beat me, and I hope you will take him;" the prisoner said it served her right, and we secured him.
NOT GUILTY .

879.
WILLIAM BLACKETT
and
ROBERT LYALL
were indicted for a
burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Emmerson
, on the night of the 26th of February , and stealing 2 gowns, value 5s.; 2 tippets, value 6d.; 2 shifts, value 4s.; 2 night gowns, value 1s.; 1 pelisse, value 15s.; 1 shirt, value 1s.; 1 locket, value 6d., and 1 ring, value 6d. , his property.

JANE PERKINS
. I live at Mr. Hemming's, in Foster-street, City
, and keep a school. On Sunday the 26th of February I went out between twelve and one o'clock at noon - I locked my door - I was sent for about eight, and found these articles on a table ready to be taken away - they were locked in a drawer when I went out; a locket, a ring, and a brooch, were gone; I have not seen them since.
Cross-examined by Mr. BARRY. Q. Do you know the prisoner? A. No.

RICHARD EDWARDS
. I was in Foster-street on the 26th of February, between six and seven o'clock in the evening - I saw Blacket at one corner of the street, and Bailey putting a key into the door of No. 3 - Lyall stood before him; I went up the street and saw Sawyer standing at the corner - I and another boy went and played in the Broadway for two or three minutes; we then went down the street again; I saw Sawyer go down and whistle - they then all went from the door - Sawyer went down the street and came to the corner again; Blacket and the others then went away - we went down again and saw the door open, which had been shut when we passed it before; we went to Walton, the officer, and told him - he came with us to the house - as we were coming down the street we saw the prisoners coming up together - Sawyer was behind them - they were coming from No. 3; we went down to the house - the officer went into the passage and said"Who is here;" the door was then opened, and Bailey said "It is me, Sir;" Walton caught hold of his collar, he wrestled in the road and got away, but left his hat behind; we found the drawers open in Miss Perkins' front parlour, and the things on the ground.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know Sawyer? A. Yes; by working at Mr. Page's; I am an apprentice to Mr. Law, in the New Market, but since last October I have been living with my mother, as I did not like the business; I have been there eight or nine months - my master is willing to take me back - he has complained of me in a Court of Justice, and I was sent to the House of Correction; I once had part of the money for which a watch was sold, but I did not take it; I believe I have run away from my master about six times; I was once taken out of a lodging house, but I do not know that it was a house of ill-fame.

COURT. Q. Upon your oath did you go to meet any girl or woman there? A. No, it was a lodging-house for men - I do not know who kept it - I was there only one night - I slept by myself - I went there about the watch concern because I was afraid to go home.

THOMAS SHROPSHIRE
. I was in Foster-street with Edwards - I saw Blacket at the corner of Half-moon-alley; it was then between half-past six and seven o'clock - we went on and saw Bailey standing, at the door of No. 3, making a noise with something, and Lyall was behind him on the curb - we went on and saw Sawyer standing at the top of the street - we went to the Broadway, and played at a step, and then we went down again, and saw them at the same place - we then went down on the same side as the house was, and saw Lyall and Bailey, two or three yards off the door - Blacket was at the same place as at first - we went round Peter-street, and came down again and saw Bailey and Lyall at the same place, and the door was open, which had been shut before; Sawyer then went down Peter-street; we went round again, and they all went different ways; we went to the officer - he went with us into Peter-street, and saw Blacket and Lyall just by a gas light in the same street, some distance off - we saw Sawyer come by, and we went to the house, and the officer knocked at the shutters, and said "Who is here?" Bailey came out, and said "I am;" the officer collared him- he struggled and got away - I went into Miss Perkins' room - I found the candle wrapped round with a black stocking, and these things about the floor - the lock of the drawer seemed to be broken.

Cross-examined. Q. Bailey was the man who came out of the house? A. Yes; I did not know them before but I can identify their persons; I am a companion of Edwards' - we had been buying some sugar - candy, and were going home.

JOSEPH WALTON
. I am the officer. These boys fetched me to Foster-street; I saw Blacket and Lyall coming up the street about two yards from the corner, as I turned into the street, about ten or twelve yards from the house - I then went to No. 3, and saw Bailey - I struggled with him and he escaped; I found the drawers open, these things on the ground, and a pick-lock key in the street-door.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know the two witnesses? Q. Yes; I had Edwards in custody from his master for running away - but he liberated him again; I did not know they were the parties till after I found them out - I knew them well, and could not be deceived in them; the boys had told me a house had been broken open, but did not say who were doing it.
The prisoners called -

WILLIAM LAWS
. I am a boot-maker, and live in East-street, Finsbury-market. Edwards was apprenticed to my father - after being a week on liking he ran away; we found he was connected with a notorious set of young thieves - my father put him into the House of Correction; he was with us, in the whole, fifteen or sixteen months, and ran away fifteen or sixteen times; he has been taken from a lodging-house in Chick-lane, and from the Royalty Theatre; he has been out three or four days and nights together, and seldom came home without being fetched.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

880.
JOHN JEFFERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of February , 6ozs. weight of tea, value 9d., the goods of the
United Company of Merchants, trading to the East Indies
.
Mr. BOLLAND conducted the prosecution.

JOHN LINES
. I am in the employ of the East India Company. I was employed to watch at their warehouse in Crutched-friars
, where some men were mending chests - they went to breakfast at ten o'clock, and soon after the prisoner came into the cellar and went to a chest - I heard his hand go into the chest three distinct times; I then went for Mr. Frazer, the elder, and said I must search the prisoner; he said he had not got any thing - but after I took him down to the counting-house he offered me a sovereign to let go his hand; I found this tea in his breeches pocket - the chest had been plundered before - he had no business in the cellar.

ALEXANDER FRAZER
. I am an elder. I saw the prisoner - Lines searched him in my presence, and about six ounces of black tea was taken from his left-hand breeches pocket.

Prisoner's Defence. I took a book from George Williams - I went to tell him he had brought a wrong number, and I asked him to change it.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined Six Months .

881.
JOHN WEAKEIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of February , 4 ozs. weight of tea, value 1s. , the goods of the
United Company of Merchants, trading to the East Indies
.

GEORGE TIMEWELL
. On Monday, the 27th of February, I was at the East India Company's sale-room, at Cutler-street
- I am commodore of that warehouse. The prisoner came into the room, and asked for some samples of tea - he had six breaks of Hyson tea set before him, and he took samples of them all - it is usual for persons to bring samples of the same sort of tea as they intend to buy; I was so placed in the room, that I could see exactly what he did - he was sampling the tea, that is, taking a small quantity from each, in a little measure like the top of a cannister, which is the limit of the quantity allowed to be taken away; there are rules stuck upon the show-room, that no persons but such as are known are to have samples, and that none of them are to have more than the in measure; as the prisoner was sampling the teas, the man who was attending to him, went to get some more from another break, and I saw the prisoner, in his absence, take some of the tea, and put it loose into his right-hand small clothes pocket - he did this several times; I told Mr. French, the elder, he told me to watch him again, and not to accuse him without good reason; I then saw him put some Hyson tea into his breast-pocket; Mr. French then desired him to walk into the counting-house, and the tea was found on him; Mr. French said, "It is a pity a gentleman like you should act in such a way;" he seemed to be quite cut up about it, and begged Mr. French's pardon, and hoped he would let him off, and not take any further notice. Mr. French said he must tell the warehouse-keeper, and he might do as he thought proper - he said he had been a long while out of work, and was very much distressed.

Prisoner. Q. Were there a number of persons in the sale room? A. Yes; I was kneeling down, your face was towards me, and your back to the corner; I cannot state what breaks of tea you took most out of - you had about sixteen trays handed to you.

COURT. Q. You saw what was going on, and informed the elder? A. Yes - the prisoner was still at the tray - when he had done he got up to go away - he took his bag and went down stairs - the elder was at the bottom, and stopped him.

WILLIAM FRENCH
. I am assistant elder to the Company. There were from twenty to thirty persons nailing up chests - when the prisoner came in, the commodore came to me, and said, "That gentleman has put some tea into his pockets - I desired him to watch him more closely, and I went down - when he came down stairs, and was going into the yard, I told him to walk into the counting-house, and said, I was very sorry to say he had got some tea - I had ordered the excise-officer to be there, and the tea was found upon him - he first said, "We were very short of samples," and then said, "I am very much distressed, and I did it for myself, being out of a situation."

Prisoner. Q. Will you swear you did not come into the room where I was, and say, "Before you go I want to speak to you"? A. No - I never once spoke to you, nor came near to you - the business was never communicated to you till you came down.

COURT. Q. When people come to buy teas, do they bring samples and leave them there? A. Yes; the prisoner brought six samples, and I counted six samples which he had in his bag - the tea in his pockets was beyound the samples he had brought.

Prisoner. Q. When you asked me if I had any tea in my breeches pocket, I said I had - you said I must leave it - and did I not give it out? A. Yes; I took up your coat pocket and turned it out - you made no resistance.

WILLIAM BATEMAN
. I was the Excise officer. I was present when the tea was found in his breeches and his side coat pockets; French took it from him, and said he had understood he had some tea - he trembled very much, and said he had, and he hoped Mr. French would not do any thing in it - he said he came from Messrs. Whitridge and Co., No. 91, Cheapside; I did not hear him say any thing about his own situation.
Prisoner. Q. Were you not in the room when I sampled these teas? A. No.

Prisoner's Defence. I was sampling the tea for some friends, having a great many friends, and having been twenty years in the business. I sampled a number of breaks of Hyson, and the sixteenth and seventeenth breaks appeared to me to be of a particular quality, and I took some of it. I do not deny taking it, but I do deny its being with a felonious intent; the last witness was at the end of the table, and twenty or thirty men were nailing down tea chests - and was it likely I should have gone to commit a felony at two o'clock in broad day. When I was asked if I had not tea I immediately gave it up.
COURT to WILLIAM FRENCH. Q. What did he say? A. I said, "How came you to take this?" and he said, "I am short of samples;" and then he said it was for himself.

JURY. Q. Is it customary to allow the parties to take their samples themselves, or is it given them by the officer of the Company? A. He takes the sample out in a tin measure - it is put into a paper, and the sample they bring is measured in the same measure.
NOT GUILTY .
London Cases, Second Jury.

882.
DONALD MEREDITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of March
, 5 pieces of paper, stamped with certain stamps of 5s. each, value 25s.; 4 other pieces, with 4s. 6d. stamps, value 18s., and 4 pieces with 3s. 6d. stamps, value 14s. , the goods of
James Smith
and
Thomas Shirley
; and
JOSEPH ZAMIRA
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well-knowing them to have been stolen .
Mr. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution

THOMAS SHIRLEY. I am in partnership with James Smith - we are wine-merchants
, and live in Crescent-place, Bridge-street, Blackfriars
. The prisoner Meredith came sometimes to our counting-house, to see his brother, who is in my employ. We have a number of stamps for use in our business, and I very frequently missed some. I accordingly put a private mark on those left in my drawer - they were 3s. 6d., 4s. 6d., 5s., 6s., and 8s. 6d. bill stamps. I made a small mark in the stamp, by which I should know them from all others. From five o'clock in the evening of the 13th of March, till nine in the morning of the 16th, I missed a considerable number - on the evening of the 17th I missed some more; Meredith had been atmy office that evening, and in consequence of something said by me to his brother, he was sent out, and returned; I saw him in the street, and he was taken to an opposite office - I asked him for the stamps - he denied having any, but I insisted upon having them, and said I had no doubt he had them on his person, and I would search him unless he would give them up - he then gave them up. I took him to my house in Chatham-place, and afterwards to the Mansion House. In consequence of information he gave us we went that evening to Zamira's house, in Duke's-place, but did not go in; we went there again on the evening of the 18th, and part of my stamps were found there. I never sell stamps in any way whatever - here are what I found on the prisoner Meredith when he was taken, and here are those found at Zamira's on the 18th - they are what I had lost on the 13th or 14th.

Cross-examined by Mr. ALLEY. Q. Then it was not on the evening you took the boy you went to Zamira? A. No; we did not go into the house till the evening of the 18th; I have about six servants; the stamps were not locked up - they were in a private counting-house; Mereditch could have access to it, because he came at eight o'clock in the morning, before the clerks came; we have three porters and two clerks, but the counting-house is never left by myself or Mr. Smith; I think only one clerk or book-keeper knew where the stamps were kept.

WILLIAM MERCHANT
. I am an officer. I went to Zamira's house, at the corner of Bury-street, St. Mary Axe, on the 17th, and on the 18th I went in with the prisoner Meredith, Mr. Shirley, and a gentleman here - we sent Meredith in, who asked if Zamira was at home; they said Yes; as I went in he was coming down stairs; I said to him "Do you know this young man," (pointing to Meredith) who was standing with his back against the door - he said No; there was no other young man in the shop; I asked what he had done with the stamps he bought of Meredith; he said he knew nothing at all about them; I then told him I was an officer; he said "Don't make a noise, I have got my house full of company;" he then spoke to his wife, or an elderly woman there, and, to the best of my recollection, it was to go up stairs, and bring the stamps down; she brought them down and gave them to Zamira - he gave them to Mr. Shirley, who identified them as his property; here are four for 3s. 6d., four for 4s. 6d., and five for 5s.; they are quite clean, and here is a mark on every one of them; we then came down to the Mansion-house; they were then committed - Meredith did not deny it or say any thing about the stamps produced - it is a kind of grocer's and stationer's shop I understand.
Cross-examined by Mr. BRODRICK. Q. Did he call to this old lady? A. No; she came without being called - he only said "Go and fetch me the stamps;" I heard all he said - he is not deaf that I know of.

PETER MURPHY
. I am an officer. I went to Zamira on the 17th, and again on the 18th, but I did not go in till the stamps were delivered.

WILLIAM NORWOOD
. I am cellarman to Messrs. Smith and Shirley. Persons come there to business at a quarter or half-past seven o'clock in the morning; I did not know before the 18th of March, where the stamps were; I have seen Meredith about the house in a morning - he used to go to the counting-house when his brother was not there; I saw him about a week or ten days before he was apprehended.

THOMAS SHIRLEY
. These are a part of the stamps which I marked on the 13th or 14th of March.
Cross-examined by Mr. BRODRICK. Q. What is the value of those bits of paper without the stamps? A. A halfpenny or a penny.
MEREDITH's Defence. Mr. Shirley gave me a promise that if I would tell all I knew he would do nothing to me.
Nine witnesses gave Zamira an excellent character.
MEREDITH - GUILTY. Aged 17.
ZAMIRA - GUILTY. Aged 56.
Recommended to Mercy .
Confined Three Months .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

883.
ANTHONY DRUMADA
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of March , 1 hat, value 5s. , the goods of
Robert Hugh Franks
.

JAMES BAYLEY
. I am in the employ of Robert Hugh Franks, a hatter , of Red Cross-street, Barbican
. On the 18th of March, a witness, named Phelps, told me some person had taken a hat from the door - I went out and received this hat from a young man who had been in the shop buying one. The prisoner was then brought back.(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM PHELPS
. I am fourteen years of age. I was in Red-cross-street on the 18th of March, about half-past five o'clock - I saw the prisoner take the hat from a peg - he said to me "Do not say any thing - come along with me;" he went a good way off with it - I did not see him stopped - I told the shopman of it.

WILLIAM PAYNE
. I am an officer. I was sent for to take the prisoner into custody - I found him in the shop, and this sack under his arm - the hat was given me by the witness - I took him to the Compter, and found four half-crowns and 4s. 6d. in his pockets.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to buy a hat, and a man gave me a push, and told me to go on; I had the hat, and some men came and took me by the collar; I had the bag to go to Billingsgate to get a job - the hat was outside the door.
JAMES BAYLEY re-examined. The hat was on a stand inside the door - a young man there saw him take it - he followed and brought him back.
GUILTY. Aged 55.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury .
Confined One Month .

884.
JOHN KELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Lowndes
, from his person .

THOMAS LOWNDES. I was in Fleet-street, near Water-lane
, on the 5th of April; I felt something press behind me, and put my hand to my pocket, and my handkerchief was gone; I turned, and the prisoner was as close behind me as he could be; I said he had taken the handkerchief, and I saw it between his feet - there were two youths behind him - he denied having taken it.
Prisoner. I saw two lads before him, and one just off the curb; he turned round and said to me he had lost his handkerchief; I said I knew nothing about it.
NOT GUILTY .

885.
WILLIAM DRAPER
was indicted for
embezzlement .

WILLIAM BROWN
. I am a fishmonger , and live in Leadenhall-market. The prisoner was employed by me to receive money. On the 7th of March he was sent to receive 10l. 17s. 6d.; he never returned to me, nor accounted to me for it; I saw him again the next night - he did jobs about the market - I had employed him at that time.

JOHN STALKER
. The prisoner called on me on the 7th of March, and asked for some money for Mr. Brown; I gave him a cheque for 10l., a half-sovereign, and seven shillings - he did not give a receipt.

ROGER JONATHAN SEABROOK
. I am a clerk at Messrs. Hanbury and Co's.; I paid this cheque on the 7th of March.

GEORGE WATTS
. I am an officer. I was informed that the prisoner had absconded, and went to Brunswick-place, New Kent-road, at nine o'clock at night, on the 8th of March - I found him in bed - there was a woman and child in the room; he delivered to Knight 9l. 13s. 6d.; I asked what he had done with the cheque; he said he had changed it, and laid some out in a pair of shoes, a shirt, and a pair of stockings.

COURT to
WILLIAM BROWN
. Q. How did you know he lived over the water? A. I received information from a young lad in the market; he had before that lived a long while in Shoreditch, with his mother; I have known him fifteen years; I thought him an honest lad
GUILTY. Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy .
Confined Six Month .

886.
CHARLES MACARTNEY
was indicted for a
burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Warwick
, on the night of the 26th of February , and stealing 3 ozs. of gold value 12l.; 15 ozs. of gold and silver mixed, value 15l., 2 pieces of silver, value 1s.; 1 piece of a spoon, value 2s.; 8 ozs. of silver plate, value 50s., and 1 sovereign , the property of the said John Warwick and others his partners.

GEORGE THOMAS SIMPSON
. I am in the employ of Mr. John Warwick - he has two partners - they are surgeons, and he is a gold refiner - they have a share in the gold refining concern. On Saturday, the 25th of February, I locked up their iron chest, about six o'clock in the evening; this gold and silver was in it; I had bought the piece of silver, just a week before; two pieces of massy silver I had bought on the 25th of Otton; I had put them into the fire and melted them in the kitchen, by his request - they came out in a particular shape, and I can identify them - the chest stood in the counting-house, which was never locked; I went into the counting-house again on Monday morning, about seven o'clock; it joins the workshop by a passage; part of the workshop is tiled in; I saw a large hole in the tiles of the workshop, enough to admit a man's body; I had not been there on Sunday - I only passed through the passage to go into the house; I then went into the counting house, the door of which was open, and I found the iron chest open which I had left locked, and missed the gold and silver, and the two massy pieces of silver; I then missed a sovereign from the till of the counter in the counting-house, which I had seen there on the Saturday night; I had locked the till, and had the key; the lock had been forced open; the lock of the chest appeared to have been opened with the key which had been in one of the partitions of the till, where the sovereign was.

Cross-examined by Mr. BARRY. Q. Was that the only money in the till? A. No, there was 3s. in halfpence, and they were taken too. The surgery business is not carried on under the same roof - they do not live there; one of the prosecutor's brothers went away on the night of the robbery - the other I saw a fortnight ago; I know that he was acquainted with the prisoner, and that he is not now to be found - the counting-house is part of the dwelling-house.

BENJAMIN WEBB
. I am constable of St. James. Westminster. I went to the prisoner's lodgings on Tuesday, the 28th of February, at No. 5, Bow-yard, Drury-lane, and found him in bed - I told him I wanted him on a charge of felony; he dressed himself, and I searched him- he refused me at first, and I observed him put his hand into his left-hand breeches pocket, and draw out something, which he dropped on the bed. I then tied his hands with a handkerchief, and looked on the bed, where I found three pieces of silver - I took charge of them immediately. I searched the room, and found a pair of shoes - the Magistrate asked at the office if they were his, and he acknowledged that they were. I went two days afterwards to the prosecutor's workshop - I observed the opening, and saw the print of a footstep ont the chimney, within half a yard of the opening; I fitted the right shoe to the footsteps - it appeared to correspond exactly - I found in the prisoner's room one new and some old crucibles, and a basin with some sort of metal in it.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you search his pockets before he dressed himself? A. No. I compared one of the shoes with the footsteps, but I did not mention that at the first examination. Mr. Warwick's brother said he did not know where he was; I took a deal of trouble to find him, but I could not. I found some property of Mr. Warwick's brother's at the prisoner's lodging.

THOMAS MORIAH OTTON
. I am an engine-turner. On the 25th of February I sold Mr. Simpson those pieces of silver - they were in one piece; I begged he would put them into the fire, to ascertain their quality; it is in the same shape as when he brought it from the fire - they are worth about 1s., and this piece of spoon is worth 1s.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean it has the same surface that it had then? A. Yes.

COURT to
BENJAMIN WEBB
. Q. Did he say how he got the silver, before the Magistrate? A. Yes - he first said that he found them in Peter's pocket, and then said Peter gave them to him.

Prisoner's Defence. On the 27th of February Peter,(the prosecutor's brother,) came to my place before breakfast, and gave me 6s. to fetch a coat from the dyer's, that wanted repairing; I repaired it for him - he said he wanted to meet a friend, and he could not go in his fustian jacket - he pulled off the jacket, and put on the coat; I removed the jacket, and the three pieces of silver fell out- he has never been found since.
GUILTY. Aged 22.

Of
stealing to the value of 39s. only, and not of burglary .
Confined Six Months .

887.
WILLIAM GOODMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of February , 3 pieces of paper, each being stamped with a stamp, denoting the payment of a duty of 1s. 9d., value 1s. 9d. each, and 21 other pieces of stamped paper, value 1s. 3d. each , the goods of
Charles Cooper
,
John Henry Cooper
, and
William Cooper
.

The prisoner
pleaded. GUILTY .
Confined Three Months .

888.
CHARLES MORRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of March , 1 iron bound cask, value 7s. 6d., 10 gallons and 1 quart of noyeau, value 5l. 12s. 6d. , the goods of
Francis Pathonier
and
Maria Weller
.

WILLIAM FAIRBAIRN
. I am clerk to Francis Pathonier and Maria Weller, distillers
, of Silver-street, Wood-street. I know this cask to be their property - there were ten gallons and a quart of noyeau in it.

THOMAS STYLES
. I am carman to the prosecutors. On the 3d of March I left the cart at the corner of Angel-street
- when I came back this cask was gone; I had left it on the cart about three minutes and a half before; there had been seven in the cart, and this laid behind, on the near side, by the tail board.

THOMAS HUGHES
. I was at the corner of St. Ana's-lane, where I saw a cart, with the name of Pathonier and Weller on it - the carman was gone up the street, and I saw a man get into the cart, and deliver this cask out to the prisoner - the other weat towards Newgate-street; the prisoner went towards Bull and Mouth-street. I and several others stopped him, and asked where he was going with it - he said a man had ordered him to take it to a place just by; he then put down the cask, but we made him bring it back. I went and got the officer.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not see the man come and ask me if I would carry a load for him? A. No. - there were five of you together.

GEORGE THOMPSON
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner and cask to Pathonier and Wellers.
Prisoner's Defence. A man came and asked me to carry this load; I said Yes, and he got into the cart.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

889.
HENRY CADE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Edward Lodge Ogle
, from his person .

EDWARD LODGE OGLE. On the 5th of April I was in Gracechurch-street
; I felt my pocket touched, turned round, and saw the prisoner with my handkerchief in his hand - I saw him drop it. I took him to the Mansion House. I had it in my pocket an instant before.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was going along Gracechurch-street - there was a sailor and another young man behind this gentleman, and directly he turned round they turned, and dropped the handkerchief - I took it up, and was going to put it into my pocket, when he took me.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

890.
WILLIAM DADE
and
JOHN GOODHALL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of March , 42lbs. of solder, value 20s.; 1 sucker for a pump, value 6d., and 7 wall-hooks, value 6d. , the goods of
Robert Hardcastle
and
Sarah Dunn
.

JOHN DUNN
. My mother, Sarah Dunn, is in partnership with Robert Harcastle. The prisoners had been in their employ seven or eight months; between five and seven o'clock on the evening of the 4th of March, I gave Goodhall the key of the solder cupboard - I then took it away, and said I had not time to lock to it, but in ten minutes after I gave him the key again to go down to the solder cupboard - he went down, with Dade and Hedley - Goodhall was below, and Dade at the top, and Hedley was handing the solder to the counting-house - I stood over the cellar looking at them - I waited for the key; when they had got it all up, I said, "Is it all up?" they said,"Yes;" I then hung up the key and went to my tea - on my return I found all the men waiting, except those three - I went after them, and found them still in the cellar - I jumped down, then Dade ran from them and I called him, but he would not come - I called Goodhall to give me a light, and I held it to Dade, and said, "Is that you?" I took him into the counting-house - he said "It is my first offence;" I said, "You have been found guilty before, but forgiven;" I sent Goodhall for an officer - he was gone some time, and in the mean time the officer came; they were taken to the watch-house - I was present when they were searched; this new sucker was found on Dade, which I believe to be my mother's - and here are seven wall-books, which I cannot swear to - but we had articles of this description; here is half of a sucker, which was found on Goodhall; this solder was found on Dade, under his coat, when I went into the cellar - it is of the same description as that they handed out of the cellar - these four pieces were secreted away, and found the following morning.

Cross-examined by Mr. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did you know of their being in the cellar? A. Not till I came down; it was necessary to clean the cellar - they went down to get coals and coke up; I found these two bars of solder on Dade - they fit our mould exactly - we make them ourselves; others may have moulds of the same shape; Hedley had the making of the suckers - it should have been hanging up - he ought to have shown it to me, but he had not; it fits the mould on which he was working.
Prisoner DADE. Q. Will you say the solder was secreted? A. It was carried across his arm.

ROBERT HARDCASTLE
. These two men were in our employ - I was in the counting-house when they came up - the witness brought Dade in to me, and said,"I have found out the thieves;" I began to remonstrate with him; he at first said he was going to bring it up stairs, and then he said, he hoped I would forgive him - he said he would make me any amends - I found these other pieces of solder hid upon some old wood where we deposit Coke.

Cross-examined. Q. What do you mean by hid? A. They were in a place where they had no business to be - there was nothing on them; I stood on tip too - the candle glanced on them; Dade said he was going to bring up the solder - Goodhall was not present; it is the custom to keep a certain quantity in the counting house; Dads did not say he had been told to bring that up to the counting-house - what he said was, that he was going to bring it up stairs.

COURT to JOHN DUNN. You mentioned that these men were gone into the cellar to fetch coals and coke - but is that usual? A. No; the labourers should do it, but they will do as they like - they do fetch them sometimes; they had the coal basket in their hands.

ABRAHAM GRIFFITHS
. I am a constable. I searched the two prisoners at the watch-house; I found on Dade seven wall-hooks and the sucker - and on Goodhall, a little bit of clack.
DADE's Defence. I had no intention of stealing the solder; I had it given me by Goodhall - and I was bringing it up when Mr. Dunn stopped me.

GOODHALL'S Defence. This solder I was ordered to get up: I returned the keys, and in the course of the evening Mr. Dunn told us to go and get coals and coke up; when I had delivered the keys to Mr. Dunn, he came running down, and went up to Dade, and said, "What have you got?" he said, "Two bars of metal to take up stais;" he called to me to get the candle, which I did - and when I came up he told me to go and get a constable, which I did.
NOT GUILTY .
SEVENTH DAY. THURSDAY, APRIL 13.
London Cases, Second Jury.
Before Mr. Common Sergeant

891.
JOHN EDWARD OAKLEY, alias JOHN EDWARDS
, was indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Mary Charles
, widow , about the hour of eight in the night of the 4th of March , at St. Botolph, Aldersgate, with intent to steal, and stealing therein 6 child's shirts, value 2s.; 3 petticoats, value 1s.; 1 frock, value 1s.; 8 caps, value 1s. 6d.; 4 shirts, value 1l. 2s.; 5 neckerchiefs, value 7s.; 3 pairs of stockings, value 4s. 6d.; 7 handkerchiefs, value 11s.; 3 towels, value 1s.; three gowns, value 7s. 6d.; 9 aprons, value 9s.; 1 cloak, value 10s.; 1 pair of sheets, value 2s. 6d.; 1 table-cloth, value 1s. 6d.; 1 shift, value 1s.; 1 shawl, value 1s., and 1 curtain, value 1s. 6d. , her property.

MARY CHARLES. I am a widow, and live at No. 5, Cox's-court, Aldersgate-street, in the parish of St. Botolph without, Aldersgate
. I rent the bottom part of the house, and have the key of that part - the landlord does not live in the house - it is all let out in tenements. I am a washerwoman. I went out on the 4th of March, at near eight o'clock in the evening; I left the property stated in the indictment there, some on my table, some in my drawer; and some in a basket. I returned in about twenty minutes; I had locked my door when I went out, and on my return I found the articles were all gone; this is the property (examining it) - it is all mine.

ROBERT LOCK
. I am a constable. On Saturday evening, the 4th of March, about twenty minutes past eight o'clock, I was in Whitecross-street, and saw the prisoner coming down, with two bundles, one under each arm; this was about half a mile from Cox's-court - I called an officer, named Bradford, and we stopped him, and asked what he had got - he said he had just come from his mother's, in Hare-court, and he met a man, who sad he would give him a shilling to carry these two bundles; I asked where he was - he said at the Merry Carpenters public-house, in Old-street. I told him I would give him every chance to find the man, and went to the house with him, but he was not to be found. I then locked him up, and in consequence of taking another man afterwards, with some kid skins, who told me I might find some more skins in a house in Gloucester-court, Whitecross-street, I went there about ten o'clock that night, and found some more property belonging to the prosecutrix. The whole are not more than one person could carry.

Prisoner. Had not he a right to take the woman into custody where the property was found? A. Witness. There was a woman frying some fish there, and I saw a trunk open - I looked at the things in it, and saw some wet mud on them, which excited my suspicion. I took them, but I did not know they were stolen - they are a part of this property.
Prisoner. The reason he did not is, because Harris, her brother-in-law, is an officer, who was with him. Witness. Yes - I called him to go with me.

THOMAS BRADFORD
. I was with hock, and took this man and the things - when we got to the watch-house it was about half-past eight o'clock.
COURT to MARY CHARLES. Q. Tell us as nearly as you can the time you left you house? A. It was just upon the stroke of eight o'clock.

Prisoner's Defence (written). Between eight and nine o'clock at night I met a tall man in Redcross-street, with three bundles under his arm - he said if I would carry two of them to the Merry Carpenters, in Old-street, he would give me 1s.
Two witnesses gave the prisoner an excellent character.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 10.

892.
SARAH SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of February , 1 fowl, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Loveday
.

JAMES THOMAS SELWOOD
. I am a salesman in Newgate-market. I saw the prisoner lurking about my shop for some hours; I then saw her go to Mr. Thomas Loveday's shop, and take a shawl off a hamper - she secreted it under her apron. I went and charged her with it; on her being removed the fowl was found under her; she had been close to the place, but when I spoke to her she had got two or three yards from it.
Prisoner's Defence. I knocked it down with my shawl.
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Confined Fourteen Days .

893.
JOHN TIPPENDEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of March , 1 rummer glass, value 1s. , the goods of
John Kingston
.

GEORGE REED
. I am an officer. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house on the 28th of March, and Mr. John Kingston gave me this glass which the prisoner confessed he had taken, and begged forgiveness - he said he was in a state of intoxication, and did not know what he had done; there were two other glasses found on him.
NOT GUILTY .

894.
MICHAEL LARNER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of April , 1 printed bound book, value 8s. , the goods of
Thomas Bumpus
.

THOMAS BUMPUS. I live at Holborn-bars
, in the City. I am a bookseller - this book is mine; I had seen it safe about twelve o'clock on the 1st of April.

JOSEPH NICHOLSON
. I am porter at the Blue Posts public-house. On the 1st of April Mrs. Bumpus called to me, about ten minutes past two o'clock, to go after the prisoner - she gave me his description; I found him in Middle-row, looking into a bookseller's shop; I brought him back, and found this book in his right hand coat pocket.

Prisoner's Defence. I cannot say I am not guilty, but the officer can tell you I was in a desperate state of madness, occasioned by a kick of a horse over my eye; I had drank some liquor that day; I was tied down in a straight waistcoat for thirty hours in convulsive fits in consequence of what I had done.
GUILTY. Aged 23.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Fourteen Days .

895.
THOMAS PERKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April , 1 wooden chest, value 2s. 6d., and 50lbs. weight of tea, value 13l. 15s. the goods of
Thomas Conway
and others, his partners.

CHARLES TOWNSEND
. I am warehouseman to Thomas Conway and others - they are wholesale grocers and tea dealers, and live in Maiden-lane, Queen-street, City. On Thursday last, the 6th of April, I loaded the cart with one chest of tea, one bag of tea, and some sugars; I gave it in charge of Blunt, the carman, about half-past eleven o'clock.

JOSEPH BLUNT
. I am the carman. I received this chest of tea in my cart on Thursday last; I drove it along Bishopsgate-street, and there I stopped; I was about forty yards behind the cart when I saw the prisoner go and move the chest of tea from the side to the tail - he then turned round and lifted it over the chain, took it on his shoulder, and walked away; I ran and caught him about half-way across the road.

THOMAS WHITFIELD
. I was sent down to Liverpool-street; I met the carman, who called and asked me to have something to drink - we were going to have it, when he turned round and said "I have a chest of tea in my cart, and I must have a sharp eye on it;" he then saw the prisoner taken it and ran after him; I saw him drop the chest, which Blunt gave me charge of, and he took the prisoner - the chest was close at his heels.

WILLIAM RILEY
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner and the tea.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going along Bishopsgate-street, and a man asked me if I wanted a job; I said Yes; he said "If you will take this chest of tea to the Catherine Wheel, I will pay for it."
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .

896.
WILLIAM PRYER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 8lbs. of beef, value 1s. , the goods of
George Lee
.

GEORGE LEE. I am a salesman at Newgate-market
. I lost a piece of beef from a book in my shop; I had seen it about ten minutes before it was taken; I saw it with a carcass of lamb which the prisoner had purchased in the morning - he paid 2s. on it; he came in the afternoon to pay the remaing 17s. 6d.; I told my man to have an eye on him - he told me he had taken a shin of beef; I ran out and saw the prisoner with the carcass of lamb, and a cloth wrapped over it - the beef was in the carcass.

Cross-examined by Mr. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did you see how it got into the carcass? A. No; it is a small piece, but it could not have fallen into it, because the beef hung under the lamb - it required some force to get it in.

WILLIAM PRENTICE
. I am Lee's clerk. On the 7th of April I saw the prisoner take a shin of beef off a book, and put it inside the carcass of lamb; I ran in and told Mr. Lee- the prisoner had a cloth which wrapped round the lamb and the beef in it.
Cross-examined. Q. Is it not usual to have a cloth? A. Yes; I told Mr. Lee the instant I saw him do it.

HENRY KELLY
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, who was very outrageous; he said he would not go to the Compter - he clung round a post, and I was forced to use a little force with him.

Prisoner's Defence. I understood the scale-man in the morning that he would hang the lamb in the back-yard, and I went there for it; the young man said it was on the right side, and he came and took the note off it; I took it on my shoulder, and some of the shins of beef fell down, one fell into the lamb, and one fell down - the man then caught the lamb and said I wanted to rob him; I said I had no idea of it; I thought it was only a joke; I then went into the market, and came back to Mr. Lee, who was talking with some gentleman; they said "Poh, Poh, nonsense!"

WILLIAM PARSONS
. I am a cheesemonger and grocer, and live in Catherine-street, Limehouse-fields; I have employed the prisoner two months, and he has always given me satisfaction, and laid out my money honestly; I was with him the day in question, when he paid the 2s. off the carcass, which he bought for me; when I missed him I called on Mr. Lee, and asked if he knew any thing of a man who had paid him 2s. off a carcass of lamb - he said he had been there, and attempted to steal a shin of beef, and he had got him safe enough, and if I would stand 2l. he would not appear against him; I would take him into my employ immediately.

GEORGE LEE
. He said the man had a wife and four children - I said I would not mention any thing but what related to his occurrence, though he has done several bad things.
GUILTY. Aged 44.
Recommended to Mercy, on account of his character .
Confined One Month .

897.
JOSEPH NIGHTINGALE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of January , 1 watch, value 1l. 12s.; 1 seal, value 12s. 6d.; 1 ring, value 1d., and 1 watch key, value 6d. , the goods of
William Charlton Wright
.

WILLIAM CHARLTON WRIGHT. I keep the Dolphin chop-house, on Ludgate-hill
. The prisoner used my house in January last - one day in that month I wrote a letter at the table, by the fire, and the prisoner was in a box at a short distance from me. I took out my watch, and put it on the table, while I used my seal - I turned round to send my servant with the letter, and in that timethe prisoner had gone out, and I immediately missed my watch, with the seal attached to it. I have not seen him since, but Mrs. Wright says he has been in the house - he had been there several times before.

Cross-examined by Mr. PRENDERGAST. Q. Had not there been some degree of intimacy between you? A. Nothing further than his being a customer. I saw he had plenty of money, and I once asked him to lend me a 5l. note - he showed me an acceptance for 50l., and asked if I could make use of that - I kept it an hour, and then returned it; I never talked about money on any other occasion - he owed me money for eating and drinking at my house; I knew his address, and wrote him two letters, which he answered - the Lord Mayor has them. The letters found him in Bride-lane, Fleet-street; I called there twice, and could not see him; I had not given orders for his apprehension - he was taken in about two months - if I had given instructions for his being taken before there can be no doubt he would have been taken.

COURT. Q. How long was it before he took the watch that you had talked about the 5l.? A. It might be about a fortnight. I did not see him take the watch, and he did not ask my leave - he never denied having taken it.

JOSEPH MARTIN
. I apprehended the prisoner on the 5th of April - he gave me a key, which he said belonged to his box, at his lodgings, at the Talbot Inn, in the Borough, and if I went there I should find a pocket-book, with the duplicate of the watch in it.
Cross-examined. Q. Where did you see him? A. At the corner of Swithin's-lane - I told him what I took him for, and he said if I would go with him to the prosecutor he would soon make it all right.

ROBERT HESKETH
. The last witness gave me a key of a box, in which I found a pocket-book, and this duplicate in it.

WILLIAM STAPLE
. I am a pawnbroker. The watch was pawned with me, by the prisoner, on the 31st of January.
Prisoner's Defence. I never took it with any felonious intention, which my prosecutor is, I believe, well aware.
NOT GUILTY .

376.
JOSEPH NIGHTINGALE
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of November , 1 silver snuff-box, value 30s. , the goods of
Thomas Lake
.

THOMAS LAKE. On the 24th of November I was at the King's Arms public-house, in Philip-lane
; the prisoner was there; we had dined at one table - the other persons were gone; and he I were alone in the room; I called the waiter to get me some snuff; I took out my box and offered it to her, and I think the prisoner reached out his hand, and handed it across the table to her - she returned with the box and some snuff in it, and gave it to the prisoner to pass on to me, I believe, but I am not quite certain whether he took it or not, but it came into his hands; he took some snuff and, in a short time, went out with the box; I did not see him again till last Saturday; I saw the box at the Mansion House - this is it; I did not know where the prisoner lived, but he knew where I lived.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you give me the snuff-box? A. Yes; I think I did, and you gave it to the waiter, and she returned it; I did not fall asleep in the interim - I got a little drowsy - I was not asleep when you left the room; I saw you go - I made no remark to the waiter about your leaving the room; I waited some time expecting you to return; I never said to the waiter, it would be all right if you had got it; she did not tell me you had it; I went two or three days afterwards to know if you had returned the box, and the answer was you had not called.

Cross-examined by Mr. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did not you put your box into the prisoner's hands? A. Yes; he took it for the purpose of handing it to the waiter, and she went out; I did not afterwards express myself satisfied that it had not been stolen; I had seen him five or six times before, but I did not see him again till Saturday last - I was very angry about it.

JANE CRAGHILL
. I live at the King's-arms, Phillip-lane. I saw the prosecutor and the prisoner there; I was called, and the snuff-box was given me to get some snuff; I did not like to go, as it was wet, and I gave it to our young man to go; when I came back, the prisoner took the box, as I supposed, to pass it to Mr. Lake; the prisoner came a day or two afterwards, and I asked him if he took the box, he said he did; I said, it was not a gentlemanly sort of action; he said I might make myself comfortable, as he would return it; he staid at the house about three hours, and had something to drink to the amount of 3s.; but he went away and did not pay - the money belonged to me.

Cross-examined. Q. On your return, did you see the prosecutor? A. Yes; he was not asleep - he told me to give the twopence to the man for fetching the snuff; he was sitting down, but I could not get at him, and I gave the box to the prisoner, but I did not see him put it into his pocket; I ran up as far as Wood-street after the prisoner, and asked him for the money; he said he would not pay.

JOSEPH MARTIN
. I received the key of the box of the prisoner, which I gave to Hesketh, who found the duplicate.

ROBERT HESKETH
. I went and found the duplicate in the box.

ROBERT ESSEX
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Aldersgate-street. I received this box in pawn on the 24th of November, for 1l.; the ticket is in the name of Joseph Nightingale; I gave the person this duplicate.

Prisoner to JANE CRAGHILL. Q. Did not I return the same day? A. No; it was late before you went away; I did not say the gentleman had been gone more than an hour.
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Transported for Seven Years .
